Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Google Maps and other highway and street GPS services have replaced what? Choices:  A: united states B: mexico C: countryside D: atlas E: oceans<n><n>### Response:		<n>A)<n>

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:The forgotten leftovers had gotten quite old, he found it covered in mold in the back of his what? A bag costs $2 to fill with groceries. Each grocery costs $6 each. There are 184 groceries. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Before getting a divorce, what did the wife feel who was doing all the work? He would get more money to buy the vehicle he always needed and not only the money he needed the original time.<n><n>### Input 2:<n>Jerome works at a company where 95% of the employees have an above average IQ. You’re constantly trying to be different from your friends, and you’re doing everything you can to stand out in a crowd. When you are older, being 17 seems like nothing; you might not even be able to remember anything specific about the age itself. I have many memories of when I was 17 years old.<n><n>### Respuesta:<n><n>17 me parece la etapa de lo más interesante de la vida. Te sientes tan fuerte y al mismo tiempo tan inseguro, te sientes invincible e indomable y al mismo tiempo un poco impotente.  Siempre estás esperando para cumplir tus 18 años y decir que ya no eres un niño.<n><n>### Para tener una mejor evaluación, el examinador necesita comprender lo que los candidatos apr

Choices:  D) 16, 5)12, A) 24<n><n>### Response:"There are 16 ounces in a gallon. A gallon is halfway between a pint, and a quart. Choices:  A: finish line B: broken bones C: broken legs D: chapped lips E: healthy body<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a single python function that takes the integer value A and B as input. The function should then return one of the possible results for each combination: A+B+C, A+B-C, A-B+C, and A-B-C. For example, if A = 5 and B = 6, the four possible results are A+B+C = 11, A+B- C = 1, A-B +C = 7, and A-B -C = -1.<n><n>### 1st Method<n><n>```python<n>def addc(A,B):<n>    add = A+B;<n>    sub = A-B;<n>    mult = A*B;<n>    minus = A-B; <n>    return (mult + add, sub + minus, sub - mult, minus + add);<n>```<n><n>### 2nd Method<n><n>```python_solution<n>def addc(x,y):<n>    return ([x+y],[x-y],[x-y]+x,y-x)<n>```<n>

How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Where could a fungus grow and not be disturbed by sunlight? How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:What might you feel after doing housework for hours? Choices:  A: living room B: dog park C: basket D: small apartment E: big house<n><n>### Response:		A<n>### Instruction<n>Write a function named "calculateDistance" that has the following signature:<n>```<n>int calculateDistance([10, 1, "5", 75.6, 15.4, 988.00123])<n>```<n>The numbers in square brackets refer to the parameters of the function. Parameters are marked by brackets [ and are positioned after the name of the function.<n>Note:- if you do not write in the first position parameter, then it is not parameter<n><n>##### Demonstration<n><n>When using the calculator or a scientific calculator on a problem involving decimals, write the appropriate operations and results on a sheet of paper. You can also take advantage of your computer's calculator by switching out the calculator icon in your start menu for the scientific calculator, for example, with MathType or Wolfram Alpha.<n>Input: -73.123<n>Answer: 73.126<n>Input: 10 / -3<n>Answer: -3.333<n>Input: 5 - 4.5<n>Answer: -0.5<n>Input: 5 * 4 * 3<n>Answer: 66<n>Input: 5+9+7+2<n>Answer: 35<n>Input: 1*2*3<n>Answer: 12<n>Input: 0 + 1 + 2 + 3 + 4 + 5<n>Answer: 50<n><n>Note: CalculateDistance() must return answers that can be expressed to 3 decimal places. These are the rules about decimal places:<n>If the first position has a number without commas or periods it will be treated as a fraction. This means you cannot use floats and if the fraction has more than 10 digits it will not count.<n>If the first number is a float, it counts as a number with commas. Do not use floating point operations except floats.<n>In the above examples the number is 12.1<n>If the first number and the first number after that are of the same type; example, if you wrote 12.008, it is considered a float. You cannot do floating point operations except floating point operations.<n>In the above example 0.088 if the first digit and the second digit are numbers with commas the

It's pretty straightforward to see that the number of legs = 6. By definition, a set is a collection of items that can have the following relationship: if one object exists, all of the other objects exist as well. If a set contains 5 objects, that means there's a possibility of 5 objects existing at one time. To find the number of objects, we can use the formula n = 6 x 5: 25.<n><n>Thank you for playing<n><n>

Choices:  A: garage B: hospital C: boat D: house E: doll house<n><n>### Response:		The easiest choice is likely to be E. A garage and a dollhouse are unlikely to have any fire extinguish. A hospital is quite likely to have fire extinguish, but it is equally as likely to have one in a boat. A house has a fair probability of having a fire extinguisher, but it is unlikely that a house would have the correct fire extinguisher for when a fire breaks out.<n>

Choices:  A: insubstantial B: massless C: dwarf D: inconsequential E: good<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input:(n=5)(m=7)<n><n>### Response:(n=10)(m=5)<n>> The 9s can be replaced by an integer from the 1 to 6 range while preserving the values of n and m.<n><n>### Input : n=5 (m=8) (k=3)<n>How many distinct sets of integers 5 can be formed if we add k to each element of the set?<n><n>> If n &gt; m, we may have k &#61; 1<n>> If m &gt; n, we may have n &lt; k &lt; 6<n>> Therefore, every time the input is n &gt; m but n &lt; k, the answer is k = 1. The result of adding k=1 to each element of a set forms a new set of integers which cannot be formed by any number of k &lt; n. Similarly, the result when k = 2, 3, 4, and 5 is different from each other.<n><n>### Response :<n>1. m &lt; n &gt; k for k = 1. Therefore the input range k = 1 is invalid here.<n>2. n &lt; m &gt; k for m = 8 and n = 5 for k = 1 to 8. For some of these values of k, the output is 8 &#61; k &lt; n &lt; 8, which is the same as k = 1. For other values of k, the answer is 8 - (k &#61; n), which is the sum of all values in the original set.<n>> For m = 6 and n = 8, k = 1 would make the output 0 (because there's only 1 item in the original set), while k = 5 would make the output 8 (because 5 is in the original set), making the output not the sum of all values of the original set.<n>3. 8 &#6364; k &#6167; 8 &#6228; k (n) &#6368; 8 (k + n). If we replace each k by 3, the result is 5 &#6366; m &

Choices:  A: complete sentence B: feel angry C: drink tea D: cross street E: park<n><n>### Response:		A (Sentence)<n><n>### Instructions:Fill in each blank with a word or words from the table provided. Write the answers in a complete sentence.<n><n>### Scoring:For each question, the question and your answer are both scored.<n><n>### Review:In the review, use the question and your answer to compare your work with the work of others. In the last question of the review, evaluate the quality of your answers.<n><n>### The word bank includes: <n><n>### The words may not occur in the same order as the question.<n>### Be aware of plural.<n><n>### Answer 1<n><n>The answer is A.  The word "been" is correct as it is in present perfect.  The sentence uses past tense.  There is also no use of the word "then" in the question.<n>##<n>### Answer 2<n><n>The answer is C.  The word "to" is correct because the second person is talking about the first person.  The first person is using "then" because he or she is talking about the past.  "I was happy.  "<n><n>### Answer3<n><n>The answer is E. The word "to" because they are both crossing streets.<n><n>###  Answer4<n><n>The answer is B.  The word "feel" is correct because they do not know if the owner will come or not.  They might feel better if the owner comes, but they also might feel worse if the owner doesn't come.<n><n>###Answer5<n><n>The answer is D.  Because they are not going to drink it, because theirs is gone, and the owner lost it.<n><n>###The word bank contains:<n><n>### Be aware that the words may not occur in this order. <n><n>### Answer6<n><n>The answer is I.<n><n>### If the owner comes, they will be happy.  If the owner doesn't, they will be sad.<n><n>### Avoiding the use of "then" at the beginning of the sentence is the correct usage. <n><n>##Response:Be aware of spelling.<n><n>##Answer 7<n><n>The answer "60" because:<n><n>### We say "How many miles has she travelled in 4 days." because we want the answer in kilom

Write a response with proper punctuation.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>> * *Please fill out the following form.*<n><n>> * *In section 1, write your name in the spaces indicated.*<n><n>> *This space is for your name and signature.*<n><n>> *Please print your full name on the space below and sign the form.*<n><n>### Writing Guidlines:<n>* *Do Not Change Anything.*<n><n>### Your response:<n><n>### Instructions<n>Task 2:<n>Below is an introduction that summarizes information found at *https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turkey* and *https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?q=Turkey&redirect=no*. Write a response (e.g., with headings) that appropriately answers the following questions:<n>1. What language(s) is(are) spoken in Turkey?<n>2. What does the word turkey mean?<n>3. Who wrote the first English cookbook?<n><n>### Demestation<n>The link between Turkey/Turkish/Turks and the food bird, the turkey, is a bit tenuous. The word has been linked since as early as 1526 when it was used in The Ship of Fools by Sebastian Münster. Before the turkey became associated with Thanksgiving, some people believed they were unclean in relation to the Passover meal. This idea was propagated at the end of the 19th century by Henry M. Lacey. The image of turkey as clean and wholesome really took off in the 1930s through government-backed ad campaigns. The USDA even issued a special “turkey-day” stamp in 1956. These efforts helped boost demand for turkey in the US – from 167,000,000 pounds in 1947 to 1,100,00,00 pounds in 2001. The turkey has now overtaken chicken and was named the number one dinner entrée

Choices:  A: shelf B: library C: classroom D: table E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```java<n>public class Solution {<n>    public String findDecision(String[] options, String[] description) {  <n>      if (!options ||!description)<n>        return "There is no dictionary.";<n>      String decision = "";<n>      String[] newOptions = new String[options.length];<n>      for (int i = 0; i < options.length; i++) {<n>        newOptions[i] = description[i];<n>      }       <n>      for(int i = 0 ;i < options.length;i++) {<n>        <n>        for(int j = 0 ;j < newOptions.length;j++) {<n>            <n>               if(options[i] == newOptions[j+1] && i!= j)<n>               {<n>                   decision = dec();<n>                   return decision;<n>               }<n>           }<n>      }<n>    }<n><n>    public String dec(){<n>      if (options[0] == newOptions[0]) return "A: " + options[1] + " B: " + options[2] + " C: " + options [3] + " D: " + options [2];<n>      else {<n>        choice = (newOptions[0]) + options[1] ;<n>        if (newOptions[1] == options[4]) return (choice + " ");<n>        else if (newOptions [2]== options[4]) return choice + " ";<n>        else choice = " ";<n>      }<n>    return choice;<n>  }<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>```java<n><n>Mom is tidying her house, where would she keep the loose dictionary?<n><n>```<n><n>## Solution Summary<n><n>You are given a list of possible locations where Mom may keep the dictionary and a list of clues that point to where Mom would choose to put it.<n><n>### Analysis<n><n>You can store information in a string[] array such that String["0"] is the first option, String["1"] is the second option, and so on.<n><n>If you are given a clue in a clue array with length 5 and the string "dictionary" is placed in location 0 of an options array, you would need to find the location of the new option in the new options array. Using iteration, you can do the following.<n><n>```java<n>for

How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Jimmy wanted a beer but his wife was an alcoholic on probation.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: neighbor's house B: bridge C: home D: homeless shelter E: prison<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Input: Jimmy wanted a beer but he did not have a permit.  Where might he get one? Choose the correct option from the list of possibilities below:<n>C: Home<n><n>Input: The bus travels at a speed of 45 miles per hour.  How many hours will it take to cover 75 miles?  The first hour, the bus travels at 45 miles per minute. The second hour, it travels at 44 miles per minute. The third hour, it travels the same. What is the average speed over this 3 hour stretch?<n>A: 44<n><n>Input: How many times can Joe play a game of Minecraft before it takes him 7 hours to complete the game? The maximum amount that he plays each hour is 1.6 times the minimum. The minimum is 8. The game starts to slow down after half an hour so the maximum amount he plays each hour is cut in half after he reaches 31 minutes of play.<n>F: 560<n><n>Input: Heidi's speed changes as she travels to the mall. Start speed: 42 mph Average speed after 5 hours: 48 mph Average speed over the whole trip: 46 mph<n>C: 42 m/h<n><n>Input: After 3 hours, the speed drops to 42 mph. What is the speed she was going after traveling for 1.5 hours?<n>B: 56 mph<n><n>Input: After traveling for 1 hour, the speed drops by 7 mph. What is her speed an hour later?<n>A: 39 mph<n><n>Input:(Cut one piece of pizza with a slice of cheese) How much cheese will be left on the pizza after removing 1/3 of the cheese on the pizza?<n>B: 1/12<n><n>Input: How much of the remaining cheese will be left after removing 1/6 of the cheese?<n>A: 5/18<n><n>Input: I buy 360 ounces  of water, with the price being $0.059 per ounce. How much does the water cost?<n>B: $13.73<n><n>Input: In total, how many ounces of

Choices:  A: theater B: refrigerator C: bakery D: grocery store E: oven<n><n>### Response:		If you didn't want to spend time in the kitchen, you would go to the bakery to buy a cake.<n><n>### Input :Alice is using a baking powder recipe that calls for one cup of flour. She just has one cup left, but does not have a measuring cup for such a small amount. She does not want to go and get one, and she does not have any measuring scoops that can be mixed in and taken out easily from the recipe. How much flour does she have remaining?<n><n>### Response :She has 40 grams of flour.<n><n>### Explanation:Alice can remove one cup, and what remains is 48g. Divide 48 by 12 to get 4. Divide 4 by 128 to get 128. Divide 128 by 128 and get 1.<n><n>### Hint:How much volume is 1 cup? How many cups are there in a pound?<n><n>### Submission:<n>[My Answer](https://github.com/julius-ngugi/Python-Problem-C/blob/gh-pages/Python_Assignments/Python_Course/Week_06_Exercise/Python_Answer.ipynb)<n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Bob and Boris were standing in a queue at the grocery store.  They were standing in place.  The line was fast, but the children in front of them were loud.   They were what? Choices:  A: frustration B: being annoyed C: delays D: irritation E: out of order<n><n>### Response:		<n>Bob and Boris were frustrated.  They were standing there for a long time and they were tired of it.<n><n>### Input<n>The clown has 5 white shoes, some red shoes, and one pair of blue shoes. One clown requires two pairs of shoes and wears one pair of his own. How many clowns can fit in the car?<n><n>### Response<n>Four clowns<n><n>### Into<n><n>Ali went to the park.  He saw a  snake and  a bug.  He walked home and saw an eagle.  How many days of the week did he go to the park?<n><n>### Respose<n>Three days.<n><n>### Invoke<n><n>Raj’s caravan is 180 feet long.  There are 20 cars behind it. There are 20 more cars from behind the first two rows. There are 13 cars behind the 20 car.<n><n>### Response A: Eighty-one.<n>### Response B: There are 180 feet behind the caravan.<n>### Response C: There are thirty cars behind it.<n>### Response D: There are eighty-one cars behind it.<n><n>## Solution<n><n>Answer: A:Eighty-one<n><n>### Explain<n><n>### Instructions:<n>We can see the 20 cars behind the 180 feet.  The 13 cars behind them, 20 + 13=33, this 33 units are behind the 189.7 feet, this is also Eighty-one cars<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Ali went to the park. He saw a snake and a bug. He walked home and saw s  eagle. How many days of the weeek did he go to the paark?<n>Answer: 1170<n><n>### Expand:<n>**A:** Ali saw the snake, the bug.  They are also the days of the weeks in the park.<n><n><n>## Test:<n><n>### Invoice:<n>Anthony baked 4 loaves of bread.  It costs $7.50 to bake 2 loafs.  How much did baking

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:What do humans do when in a race? Therefore, when the ground is wet, what is happening nearby is melting of ground.<n><n>#### Explanat:<n>When it rains, what are the choices given for the answer of A and B?<n><n><n>When the ground is getting wet, which of the following is the closest choice in meaning?<n><n><n>What did we just explain to show: The ground is getting wet, due to the water on the earth'skin surface.<n>

How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Sam was against Allison's decision.  Joe was the opposite.  What was Joe, regarding that decision? Choices:  A: being for B: away from C: combined D: for or E: conjunction<n><n>### Response:		D.<n><n><n>### Input : The distance between your house and the store is 4km. If you walk at the same speed, how long does it take you to each of those places?<n><n>> A: going to the store takes 80 minutes.<n><n>> B: getting home takes 35 minutes.<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>```js<n>(1)<n>>> A<n>>> B<n>>> A and B<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Below is a code snippet that generates a number. <n>```js<n>const seedNo = 0;<n><n>function getUniqueSeed () {<n>    seedNo++;<n>    return seedNo;<n>}<n>```<n>How many unique seeds will be generated before the function reaches the seed that has already been produced?<n><n>### Code:<n>```js<n>getUniqueSeed();<n>```<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>The next produced seedNo is going to be larger than the previous one. It will run the function a second time, and the result produced will be another number.<n><n>It will increase the number 4 times, and then it will be 16, a 16th number, which results in another 0.<n><n>The program will be launched 17 times, and the result will be `17`, which is the 17th number.<n><n>### Input<n>The number of birds in a small woodlands is 15% of all birds. If the number of birds in the entire country is 680 Million, how many birds are in the forest?<n><n>### Answer<n>```js<n>function solution(input){<n>    input = input.parseFloat();<n>    const result = 15*input;<n>    return result;<n>}<n>```

He would get up in the morning, and then put them in what state again? Choices:  A: upside down B: in motion C: active D: wakefulness E: resthold<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>import sys<n><n><n>def GetBouncingBall(input_string, input_size):<n>    balls = input_string<n>    return input_string[input_size-1]<n><n>def Pause_Bouncing_Ball( balls, state, s ):<n>    # state=  A: upside B: in motion C=active D = wakefulness E rest hold<n>    # s= index in balls list<n>    for index in s:<n>        if balls[ index ] == state:<n>            print("The bouncy ball is ", state, s.index(index))<n>            return state<n>    else:<n>        new_state = GetBouncingBal( balls, ball_size = s)<n>        return new_state<n><n><n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    input = sys.stdin.readline()<n>    balls_string = input.strip()<n>    s = 0<n>    bounce_status = input_string[0].lower()<n>    test_string = bounce_status <n>    #print test_string<n>    print("Pause_Bouncing Ball")<n><n><n><n><n><n>    while bounce_status:<n>        balls_string= balls_string + bounce_status<n>        print("The bouncery ball ", balls_string)<n>        #s+= 1<n>        if  bounce_status == 'a':<n>            bounce_status = GetBouncingBal( balls_string, ball_size = len(balls_string) )<n>        #return<n>```<n><n><n><n><n>### Solution: You can write your own code to complete the task. If your solution matches the solution we have provided, we will not review it.<n><n>### Solution for Input:15 is divisible by 3, but is not divisible by 5.<n><n>### Answer: The integer 14 is divisible by 5, but it is not divisible by any higher prime factor.<n><n>### The following task involves solving a problem through iteration and recursion, respectively.<n><n>### Task: In the next 3 problems, you should write a program that prints the sum of all prime numbers < limit. You should use recursion and iterative approach to solve each case.<n><n>### Problem 1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:When I was home, I was comfortable.  But I had a crippling fear of going where? Choices:  A: suitcase B: department store C: safe deposit box D: these twos are not safe way to transport jewellery E: lady's boudoir<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### Question 1:<n>```python<n>#!/usr/bin/python3<n># -*- coding: utf8 -*-<n>answers = 56<n>return str(answers), 0<n>answer_flag = 1<n><n>```<n><n><n>```python<n># Import the needed libraries.<n>import sys<n>import re<n>```<n><n>## 41) How Many Apples?<n>  The task asks how many apples were on display in a fruit stand.<n><n>One apple costs \$2.40, and 10 apples costs \$26.<n><n>How many apples were on sale?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a program to answer the question in the following description.<n><n>### Explanation of Solution:<n>### Input:<n>```python<n>fruit_stand_apples = 10<n>fruit_stand10 = 26<n>```<n><n>### Output:<n>```python<n>if (fruit_stand_fruit <= 10) and (fruit_stand1_apples):<n>    return str(10) <n>elif (fruit_standfruit_10 <= 10) or (fruit_standapples_ <= 10):<n>    return str("26")<n>```<n><n>## Explanation of Answer:<n>This example shows that you can use two OR statements to make a complex decision. The above solution will return 26 if there are less than 10 apples, and return 10 if there are 10 or more apples.<n><n><n>## 42) A 5-Step Process<n><n>The task describes the steps in a 5-step recycling process. Write a program that asks the user how many steps there are in the 5-step recycle cycle.<n><n>Each step is worth a different amount of time for the work.<n><n>### Input<n>```python<n>5 <n><n>```<n>### Explanations of Solution<n>1. First, find the string from the code for the number of steps in the cycle.<n><n>2. Secondly, store the string in a variable.<n><n>3. Then return the variable.<n><n>```python<n>if number_of_cycle <= 5:<n>    return str(number_of_cycle)<n>``` <n>##

What percent of the total distance did he cover in errands?<n>Answer: 2.3%<n><n>Input: When working for the supervisor, the student earned a 78% in one class and a 76% in the other class. What grade-point average did she earn in that class?<n>Answer: <n>### Input:Answer the multiple-choice question below.   <n>### Explanation: The total distance Peter runs is equivalent to the total number of classes he takes. And since he received a GPA of 0.3, this means that he received a grade of 30% in each of those classes, which means the probability is 30% times 2, as there are 2 classes, which equals 60%. It is therefore true that there is a 60% probability that he earned an "A" overall!<n><n>### Instructor Response<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instruption:Answer the following multiple – choice question.<n><n><n>### Demonsatration:<n>Input A: A supervisor tells an employee to complete 150 jobs in a week. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:After new coke was discontinued what formula was used? Choices:  A: original B: old C: coke clear D: former E: familiar<n><n>### Response:		Answer: D<n><n>### Input(s): Adam bought 3 kilogram of nuts and 1 pound of dried fruit at a store. nuts cost $12 and the dried fruit costs 25. How much did the purchase cost?<n><n>### Response(s): Answer: 35<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question in which the answer will be an odd number between 20 and 100.<n><n>### Inputs: Dollie buys 3 pairs of shoes and 2 shirts. The shoe prices are $45 and $25 and the shirts are $5 and $30. What is the total cost of her purchases?<n><n>### Answer: 94<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Inputs: Adam buys 3 kilograms worth of dried fruits, 2 grams of nuts and 3 liters of water. Nuts cost $12 dollars and the water costs $8 a liter. How much did Adam spend?<n><n>Input(s): Adam bought a 3 kilogram of dried fruits and 2 grams of cashews at the market. The prices were $8 a kilograms and $50 a gram. How much did his purchase cost?<n><n>Input: Dollie buye 4 kilograms of nougat and 3 liters drink. The nougat cost $55 and the drink cost $50. How much did her purchase cost?<n><n>Instructions:How does the answer of the problem above match with the input of the question below? Answer: It has to be C.<n><n>Instructions(s):Answer the following multiple choice problem. Each of the choices is a correct multiple choice answer to an earlier multiple choice question.<n>

Fuel prices also went up by 20%. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Someone who doesn't care about about someone else and wishes them to fail has what feeling towards them? Choices:  A: unfeeling B: negligence C: antipathy D: indifferent E: rapport<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:The program must read and write a string that contains a single word (up to 100 characters), lower case or upper case. Print the string on the screen.<n><n>### Your Code:<n>Input: A B C D E F G H<n>Output:<n><n>### Demos:<n>Input: <n>Output: A<n>Input: <n>Outpuut: B<n>Inpuot: <n>Output: C<n>Input: <n>output:<n><n>### Requirements:<n>The program must read and print a single line (up to 1,000 characters) that follows certain format. <n>The character used to separate words must not be part of the first word. <n>The program should print the lines on the screen.<n>### Your Code<n>Input: Hello<n><n>Output: hello<n><n>### Demo<n><n>## Instruction:<n>The program must accept a string of up to 100 lower case characters. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:The crab was scuttling but strained when he moved, what was impeding him? The population of a conuty 30% larger than the first city also dropped by the same percentage.  What percentage of the total population did these two cities combined make up before the decrease? <n><n>### Response<n>Input: The population dropped by 25% for both cities, which means the percentages didn't change.<n><n>### Input<n><n>The city of San Francisco had a population of 830,000 people, and as the city grew, the city council approved plans to increase the height of every building by 2 feet.  They did this to avoid having any building rise 9 feet above every other building, which is the standard practice in the city. They ended up increasing every building by 20%.<n>Input: Every building in the city got 20% bigger.  To figure out what percentage the city increased overall, you would consider how many people lived in each building, not how tall their building is. <n><n>### Demos<n>Input: Every 18 people lived in a house, how many houses would it take to accommodate 100 people? <n>Answer: 5<n><n>Input: Every 6 yards in a football field are 10 feet and therefore equal 1 yard and a touchdown. You don't really need an explanation<n><n>* Demo:<n>### Answer:<n>This is an example on what the writer will need to write or say<n><n>### Instction:<n><n>This is just asking a question.<n><n>##Instructions:<n><n>You're having to answer the question with the provided materials.<n><n><n>

How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:What do people who are speech therapists do? Choices:  A: make music B: believe in god C: give speeches D: complete sentences E: build houses<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructio:Write the code for the program<n><n>### Demstration:<n>[![code demo](../publicSource/images/todo_code.gif)](https://gfycat.com/SavageEminentPorcupine)<n><n>### Solution:Code<n>```C#<n>        class Program<n>        {<n>public static void Main()<n>            {<n>                var prompt = "Input:\nQuestion:\nDemonstration:\nSolution:";<n>                string answer;<n>                bool gotIt = true;<n>                while (gotIt)<n>                {<n>                    string input = "";<n>                    var intAnswer = int.Parse(Console.ReadLine());<n>                    Console.WriteLine($"{prompt}");<n>                    do<n>                    {<n>                        input = Console.ReadLine();<n>                        gotIt = Console.ReadLine() == "Y/y";<n>                        if (gotIt == false)<n>                        {<n>                            break;<n>                        }<n>                        //Console.WriteLine(intAnswer);<n>                        switch (intAnswer)<n>                        {     <n>                            case 3:<n>                                Console.WriteLine("A");<n>                                break;<n>                            case 5:<n>                                Console\.WriteLine("B");<n>                                break;\<n>                            case 4:<n>                                Console\>.WriteLine("C");<n>                                break;;<n>                            case 6:<n>                                Console>.WriteLine("D");<n>                                break:<n>                        }<n><n>                    } while (false) ;<n>                }<n>                <n>            }<n>        }<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: library B: demonstration C: corner D: football ground E: rug<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demand:How many miles did you walk in 4 days?<n>### Response:<n>### Code<n>### Answer:<n><n>### Description:Walk 1 mile a day in 4 days<n>### Calculation:Day 1 -> Miles walked: 1 Day 2 -> Miles walked: *(Walk 1 mile on day 1 + *2 days) -> Miles walked: = 3 total Miles walked: 6<n>### Answer:6 miles walked<n><n>### Note:<n>Walk = 1<n>Walk = 2<n>Walk = 3<n>Walk = 6<n><n>### Examples:<n>### Example 3:Input: Miles Walked = 4<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Input: Miles Walk 1: 1 Miles Walk 2: 2 Miles Walk 3: 3 Total Miles Walk 4: 6

The blank refers to a word missing in the statement.<n><n>### Example:<n>This ________ a good place to go for cheap housing.<n><n>### Incorrect: a<n><n>### Correct: This is ________ a good p<n><n>### Example 2:<n>His ________ a good source of nutrients.<n><n>### Correct; His is ________ good sou<n><n>### InstructiOn:<n>### DemonstRatioN:<n><n>### Example:(4,7,-5).<n><n>### Demandstration: <n><n>### Example Incorrect:(4,7,-,5)<n><n>### Demstration:<n><n>### DemosTRatioN:<n><n>#### Answer:<n>4-5.<n><n>### Reaction:<n><n>### Demo: <n>4+5=9.<n><n>### DeMaSt.<n><n><n><n>

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:When we are thankful for getting something what do we do? They love adventure and traveling.  <n><n>Others don't really do a whole lot of activities.  <n><n>Instead, they seek out a really nice place to stay.  A good, quiet beach.  A cool pool. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:We do not have rest, so how are we feeling? Choices:  A: exhausted B: lonely C: worked all day D: were very tired E: feel better<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>This task uses an algorithm called the Exhausted Checker to figure out whether you are or are not feeling exhausted. If you are, the program will display your choice.<n><n>Below is an explanation of the steps the program takes to reach its conclusion.<n><n>  1. Make 8 random selections from the alphabet letters from A to E in no particular order.  Then put them in no particular order except for the letters C, D and E.  <n>Example:  <n>A, D, E, F, G, H, J, K, and B are the order chosen.  <n>2. Get all of the letters in the alphabet besides the letters C, D, and E.  <n>This gives you a list of all the letters except for the four randomly chosen letters that are included in the first step.  <n>In the case of our example:  <n>"ABFGHJK", which leaves us with letters A, F, G, and J.  <n>3. For all letters, pick a random number from 1 to 9.  <n>"A" = 4  <n>"F" = 6  <n>"G" = 4   <n>"J" = 3  <n>4. Combine the letters and the random number to create a new string.  <n>"AD", "EJ", "GF"  <n>5. Check if the letters are in the alphabet.  <n>"AD" = true  <n>"EJ" = true  <n>  "GF" = false  <n>6. Check if the letters start with A to E.  <n>"AD = false  <n>"EJ = true  \<n>"GF = false  \<n><n>7. If the letters that are in the alphabet and in the order A, B, C, D, and/or E are in the same string, check if that string equals the result of putting in a set of 8 random letters in an alphabetically ordered way except for two letters and one more letter.  <n>In the example above:  <n>7. "AD". AD = "AD". True  <n>"EJ". EJ = "EJ". True  <n>"GF". GF = "EJ". False<n><n>8. Output the choice and return back to the main program.<n>For each possible choice, display a single character letter.  <n>The following example

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:james loved the stars.  In the wilderness, they lit up what? Choices:  A: outer space B: night sky C: universe D: orbit E: the ground<n><n>### Response:		D<n>

Choices:  A: run programs B: play games C: control model D: power down E: reason exists<n><n>### Response:		 C<n><n>### Commentary:<n>- We can use a list to store multiple choices:<n>  - list = ["A", "B", "C", "D", "E"]<n>  - choice = "which to choose"<n>    - e.g. choice = "Choose the item which best suits you."<n>  - do (for i in 1:len(list)){print(list[i])}<n>- We can ask multiple choices using question mark(?) instead of comma.<n>- We can also ask the user to press 1 for choice 1, 2 for choice 2... <n>

She picks 1 bead without replacing it in the bag. Then she replaces 15 beads and picks another bead without replacing it. She repeats this process over a two-hour period. How many total beads are picked?<n><n>### CORRECT ANSWER <n>**257**<n><n>### EXPLATION:<n>The first time she picked 15 beads the second time she picked 226 beads making a total of 227 beads. The third time she picked 14 beads because she already picked the one before she picked them. The fourth time she picked 16 beads because she picked one when she did the first time. The fifth time she picked 17 beads the sixth time she picked 18 making a total of 11 in a bag of 257 beads.<n><n>### Solution Explanation:<n>**CORRECT:** 227 + 226 + 221 + 214 + 208 + 203 = 1111<n><n>### EXPLAINTION<n><n>### INPUT:<n>Sonia, Lisa and Kylie took turns to throw dice and move along a track. Choices:  A: determination B: upper hand C: superior D: higher position E: skill<n><n>### Response:		The answer is <n><n>- In chess, a position is when there is only one move for either side.<n>- Determation simply means your concentration and focus on what is in front of you.<n>- Upper hand means that you have the lead but you still need to play good to retain it.<n>- Skill means the skill that you have to stay ahead compared to the other players.<n>- Higher position means the position you are in.<n><n><n><n>

But if we need to seek sources to pass time, I will watch the news on television.<n><n>### Input<n>Bella goes to the movie every Friday night. Last season, she watched 2 movies each week. On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:What does exercising immediately lead to? Choices:  A: relaxation B: exhaustion C: energetic D: become stronger E: use energy<n><n>### Response:		What is the correct answer to this question?<n><n>A: relaxation<n><n>A: relaxing<n><n>B: exhaustion<n><n>B: energetic<n><n>C: exercise<n><n>C: working out<n><n>D: more energy<n><n>E: becoming stronger<n><n>### Input-Response Form<n><n>The input-response form describes the user's intent and the interaction design of the system. In this form the first is the name of the user who requests the system to perform the task and the second is the input that the user requests the system to perform and the third is the response that the system must provide.<n><n><n>### Example<n><n>Input: John wants to know the temperature outside.<n>Input: Jane wants to know the weather forecast for tomorrow.<n>Input-Response Form:<n>John: Get Temperature (Input) <n>John: Show Temperature (Response)  <n>Jane: Get Weather Forecast (Input) <n>Jane: Show Weather Forecast (Response) <n><n>### Example Response<n>```<n>John: Show Weather Forecaster (Response)<n><n>The temperature outside is 45 degrees Fahrenheit and sunny. The high this afternoon will be 50 degrees. Sunny weather will continue until tomorrow.<n>```<n><n>### Categories<n><n>- Input:<n>    - The user's request<n>- Request:<n>    - The task that the user requests the AI to perform<n>- Response:<n>    - The system's response
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. Remove one at a time. Find the number of times a red marble is picked. Hint: Let n be m.<n><n>### Response1 Response: <n>Red marble is picked 5 times.<n><n>### Question1<n><n>- How was this solved?<n><n>> Inserting n = m in the statement "Remove one from a time."<n>- Why is red marble picked 5 times?<n><n>> It's the inverse function of n = 5<n>- How do you know that statement?<n><n>> From solving inverse function<n><n>### Example2 Input: Find the number of books in a shelf with 25 books in total and 4 shelves. You open each shelf in turn, and at any time, you are guaranteed to get a different book. Hint: What are the two numbers that appear as often as any other?<n><n>### Response2 Response: <n><n>Two numbers that appear as often are 5 and 9, because there are five books in each shelf and nine books in each shelf.<n>Thus the number of books in each shelf is five.<n>The total number of books in 4 shelves is four times 5 which is 20.<n><n>Now there are twenty additional books that have to be place in the bookshelf.<n>To place each additional four times the number of books in that shelf.<n><n>### Example3 Input: Two identical dice are rolled. Choices:  A: public building B: tomb C: arena D: large building E: treasure<n><n>### Response:		Choice E (treasure)<n><n>### Input : There is more than enough food to share.  They all get 1 piece.  Choices: A: A bit less than half B: More than half C: Exactly half D: Less than half E: The exact amount you wish to eat<n><n>### Response : Choice A (A bit less than half)<n><n>###  Instruction:The following task involves a question followed by three statements. You have to decide whether the statements follow logically from the information given.<n><n>### Statements 1:<n>One of the statements will logically follow if, or only if, the answer to the question is True.<n><n>Question: How many more students are in the Math class than in the Science class?<n><n>### Statement 1:<n><n>The number of students in the Math class is the same as the number of students in the Science class.<n><n>Answer: False<n><n>Reasoning:<n>In the given scenario the answer is: Yes, Math class has more students than Science class.<n><n>So, choice C is the right answer.<n><n>### Choice of statements 2:<n>One of the other statements does not give a logical conclusion based on the question and answer.<n><n>Question: It rained today.<n>Answer:  False<n><n>### Choices of statement 2:<n><n>1. It was yesterday that it rained.<n>2. It was yesterday that yesterday it rained.<n>3. It was yesterday's day that it rained. <n><n>### Statment 3:<n><n>Statement 3 will follow if, and only if, the answer is True.<n><n>Reasoning : If the answer to the question about whether it rained is False, then statement 3 is impossible.<n><n>The question can have different answers, because both "Yes" and "False" can make statement 3 impossible.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>Statement 2:<n><n>### Explanation:<n>If there was a girl named Sarah, then there are only girls named Sarah in the world. That means that if you were on an island and you met another girl named Sarah, then she is the only Sarah who is there on the island. Statement 2 is false and statement 3 is impossible because there might be a couple girls named Sarah on the island.<n><n>###

Everest, mt. Kilimanjaro, etc)<n><n>### Response -:<n>Mount Kilimanjaro is a dormant volcano that stands about 30 miles away from the city of Moshi.<n><n>### Task: <n><n>Write a program that asks the user to enter a string, and display whether the string contains multiple capital letters or not.<n>### Input:<n>Input from:<n>User: What is the string?<n><n>User: What should you return?<n><n>User: Type "yes" if the string contains capital letters and "no" if it does not.<n><n>User: Give me the capital letters please.<n><n>User: (Please enter a string.)<n><n>### Response <n><n>User: [Input the string] contains capital letters.<n><n>### Output:<n>### Task: A user asks you to calculate the area of the lawn.<n>Write a program to calculate the area of a rectangular land based on the information given.<n>### Requirements:<n><n>The land is 70 feet wide. It is also 48 feet deep.<n><n>### Example:<n>Area = 2056 sq. ft.<n>### Output:A 70 ft × 48 ft land will measure 3,728 square feet or 40 x 650 sq. in.<n>### Task:<n>Write a program to find the total area of the lawn based on the number of plants and the length of each plant.<n><n>#### Input:<n>A user asks you to calculate his lawn area. The user’s lawn is 80 ft x 50 ft,<n>and each plant is 12 inches long. He has 20 plants total.<n><n>#### Example:<n>20 plants × 12 in × 80 ft = 8,160 sq. in<n>8,160 square inches converted into feet is 53 square feet.<n>80 ft x 12 in = 960 in/ft<n>960 divided by 20<n>960/

The student chose D and wrote Fill them up. The verb fill is correct but there needs to be a ‘them’ which is not stated in the solution. This is an example of how a student who has mastered the skill of reading for key-words could get the answer correct, but a student who had to decode every word needs additional practice of the skill to improve this level of reading.<n><n>The solution given ‘They are full, so we had to put some more gas, in order to fill them. Up’ is grammatically incorrect in structure and has numerous spelling errors.<n><n>To improve on their errors in spelling and structure, this student would need to practice making correct sentences. To do this effectively they need first to recognize the errors made and then be given feedback on those errors.<n><n>To help them better recognize the errors they made, you could draw attention to the errors made and why they are errors by providing a rubric or criteria with feedback, in the future. Then the errors may jump out at them.<n><n>## Instinct:Answers the following multiple-choice questions.<n><n>## InstuctioN:Answer the question below with choices a,b,c, and d. This information can be used in a number of different ways, each of which could lead to the same, correct answer.<n><n>The task then goes on to give a number of choices that could be used to solve the task.<n><n>### Input Choices<n>- One set is one dozen<n>- Each of the 12 eggs represent 2.5% of the 48 eggs available<n>- One dozen eggs is 2.5% over the original 48 eggs<n>- The next task involves multiplying a set of numbers<n><n>### Response Choices<n>- 925<n>- 20<n>- 752.5%<n>- 49*1.025^3<n><n>### Response Guidance:<n>One set is one dozen, each of the 12 represent 48 out of 480, 480 – 48 = 432, 12/432 = 2.7%.

Choices:  A: death B: coma C: peace D: forgetfulness E: loss of life<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### InputJames, an accountant and a keen sports fan, won 10 Premier League tickets in a competition.  If he has 5 friends who are also keen sports fans (or any sports-lovers who have a Premiership team as their favourite), how many tickets can he take to the game?<n><n>### ResponseD<n><n>Ans=10<n>B=20<n>C=50<n>D=100<n>E=200<n><n>### Question:<n>In the code below, the variable "size" indicates the total number of tickets won.  The "numPrem" and "numOther" variables, on the other hand, indicate the number of Premiership tickets, and non-Premiership tickets, respectively.  <n>How can the code be changed to find out the difference in the number of tickets? i.e. How many Premier League and how many non-Premier League tickets have been won?<n><n><n><n>### Code:<n><n>```python<n>for i in range(1,numPrem):<n>    size+=1<n>    numPrem-=1<n><n><n>for i in range (1,numOther):<n>    size+= 1<n>    numOther-=1<n><n>numPrem*100/100 <n>numOther*100/200 <n><n>```<n>### Solution:<n>```python<n>for j in range(1, numPrem):<n>    print("Sports team:")<n>    for q in range (1, 11):<n>        if (numOther <=10 and q < numOther):<n>            print(q + "x", 'Other')<n>        else:<n>            print(q)<n><n>with open("result.txt", 'wt') as file:<n>           for i in range (1, size):<n>            for j in range(2, 11): if (i > numPrem+numOther):print(j+"x" + "Premier")<n>             else:print(j+"xOther")<n>```<n>### Output:<n>```python<n>Sports team:<n>       1x Other<n>       2x Other<n>       3x Other<n>       4x Other<n>       5x Other<n>       6x Other<n>       7x Other

As he is walking toward the door, he sees that he has an invoice for payment from the vendor that had delivered some parts that he has not gotten around to ordering for his new project. He picks up the invoice and is just about to turn to the front when he sees a few more people coming out of the building to the sidewalk.  They are coming out a different exit than where he is going so he decides he can make it to the front before he has to pull out again.  He gets inside and has just enough time to say hi to the admin assistant before finding the stairs to get to the second floor where his office is.  He notices a few stray people on the floor heading toward his door and makes a mental note to let them in.  Just then a few people he knows walk in but before he can get to his door there is a group of people at the stairs.  It is getting later in the day so not sure where they came from since they did not work on this floor.  He stands in the door and waits patiently for them to figure out how to get up to the second floor.  One by one they notice the up arrow sign and begin to slowly move toward the stairs.  As they gather on each flight Tom is in their way so he steps up to the top and waits.  He then takes the time to glance at the invoice and sees the parts that he had ordered and was expecting to get as well as a reminder that he should take delivery of them sometime in the next couple weeks. Choices:  A: trash can B: honey C: bouquet of flowers D: rose garden E: field of flowers<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>import re<n>import math<n><n>def flower_color (flower_color):<n>if flower_color =='red':<n>	return 'A'<n>elif flower_color == 'yellow':<n>	return 'B'<n>elif flower_colour == 'purple':<n>	return 'C'<n>elif flower_colonour == 'white':<n>	return 'D'<n>elif flower_comolour == 'blue':<n>	return 'E'<n>else:<n>	return flower_color<n>```<n><n>### Input and Output<n>```python<n>input: flower_color, output: flower_color<n>input: flower_comolour, output: color_comolour<n>input: flower_colonour, output: flower_colonour<n>input: flower color, output: flower_comol<n>```<n><n>## The answer is **none of the above**<n>### Input:<n>A red-toothed woodpecker<n>### Instruction<n>Complete the sentence by selecting an appropriate response from the list.<n><n>### Options:<n><n>#### Answer:<n>The bird is a male.<n><n>```python<n>a = input('a red toothed woodpecker.')<n>b = re.search('male',a)<n>b<n>```<n><n>```python<n>def is_female(bird):<n>if bird == 'female':<n>	return True<n>else:<n>		return'male'<n>```<n><n>## Instruction<n>Complete the statement.<n>You can also change the following sentence to fit the context.<n><n>### Option:<n>Answer: My favorite drink is **Cider**.<n><n>```python

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:The skin was cut while chopping onions, where was this skin likely cut? Choices:  A: good health B: finger C: meat D: body E: own family<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:If you aren't glad, unhappy or gloomy, what illness may you have? Choices:  A: depressed B: downcast C: angry D: unhappy E: sorrowful<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demystifying Solution Techniques<n>**Explanation:** To help you with the programming task that we shared above, we need to understand the solution techniques and code formats that are used therein.<n><n>The first technique that we should be concerned with is _reading and understanding the instructions_. We’ll get the instructions from any of the input sources we can find, and we’ll break down the instruction into multiple comprehensible clauses.<n><n>We can use [this](https://thecodingmachine.com/posts/coding-jobs-interviews/coding-tips/how-to-read-and-understand-any-coding-problem/) article by TheCodingMachine to know how to read complex, text-based programming instructions by breaking them down into multiple comprehensible sub components.<n><n>The second technique to be concerned with is the _breaking-down of instructions into a program sequence_. Our steps might be simple, but it might get difficult at times to understand which step in the sequence comes first and which comes last—we could use [this](https//thecodingmachine.co/posts/codinginterview/coding-tipsi-step-bystep/how-to-break-down-coding-problem) article to demystify this step.<n><n>The third technique to be concerned with, at least for some of the coding tasks we’ll see, is the use of [combinations](https://thecoderpad.com/blog/2015/12/30/27-computer-science-problems-explained/) to solve a task. Using combinations to solve a task works when there is a need to solve the task in different ways, each with its own logic and algorithm.<n>

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Where would you find a bee gathering pollen? How much was his purchases for?<n><n>### Response; 56<n><n>This person bought 56 kilos of product, the answer is 3( nuts) + (12 *3) and ( dried fruits) = 56( 1.8 kils *12) + (2.5 kilgs *8) = 13,520. Choices:  A: improve yourself B: become knowledgeable C: have tools D: persistence E: have more knowledge<n><n>### Response:		The correct words are A and D<n><n>#### A.<n><n>You need to improve yourself first, before improving your skills and abilities.<n><n>#### D.<n><n>If you want to learn, you need to have the right book and be persistent with improving yourself. As knowledge increases with age, so does skill level. Therefore, the more knowledge and skills we gain, the more we increase.<n><n>### Tips<n>1. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:If you want to make a big splash in a river with a rock, from where should you throw it?
