How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:The game was on sale.  I got it then because it was usually what? Choices:  A: buying B: purchase C: overpriced D: way to much E: expensive<n><n>### Response:		 A: buy<n>![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72462422/167208828-b4564a6e-14b4-4bb0-b8e9-c8e889aecf81.png)<n><n>**[View on GitHub](https://github.com/akulya-yogi/CS401-Academic-Year-2020-2021/blob/main/Assignments-and-Weekly-Tasks/Task-2-Instruction-and-Answer/Task-2A.md**)**

How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:What is the hope of playing sports without competition? Choices:  A: running B: have fun C: balls touch D: winning E: get tired<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple answer questions.<n><n>### Question 1:A truck is loaded with 20 400-pound bags of potatoes.  Each bag has 10 pounds of potatoes.  How many pounds are in each truck? <n><n>### Question:10/400=0.025<n><n>### Question2A: A boat was filled with 4000 cups of water. The boat holds 1500 gallons of water. How many gallons of water were remaining after the boat was filled?<n><n>### Response2A:2500 gallons<n><n>### Question3A: Three workers complete a painting job in 3 days. A second group of workers would complete the same painting job in 10 days. How many more workers would be necessary?<n><n>### Question4A: A company manufactures 50 bags of popcorn kernels. Each bag weighs 6.5 pounds.  How many pounds of popcorn kernelets did the popcorn company manufacture altogether?<n><n>### Instructons:Choose one of the two following answers.<n><n>### Choice1.The carpenter wants to build a large deck out of 2/4 inch lumber measured in 12 feet. She estimates that a single liner board would only be 8 foot. At most, how many lines of lumber would she need for the deck?<n><n>### Answer1:The carpenter needs a total 24 foot of lumber.<n>### Choice2. A baseball team gets paid 10% more than its opponent. The total salary is $25,000,000, and the opponents' salary is $29,800,00.  By what amount is the baseball team paid more from the opponents?<n><n>### A: $480,000<n><n>### Instuctions:Choose one of three following choices.<n><n>###  Choice1: A 500 gallon drum is filled to the brim as 10 5<n><n>gallon jugs of liquid. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Sarah wanted to by a new rug.  Ink spilled onto her old one.  Really, she didn't know what that thing had an inkwell in the first place.  What piece of furniture might have been on her run? Choices:  A: front of door B: bedroom C: desk D: table E: living room<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Explanation:<n>My response is D. I want to prove that it is D.<n>When I look at all the choices, I choose the option that seems the least likely. When it comes to an antique sofa, a living room sofa makes the most sense.<n>Sarah is more likely to be living in the living room.<n><n>**Note:**This solution is correct, but not necessarily a perfect solution.<n>

How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:James chose to not to print the cards, because he wanted to be more personal. What type of cards did he choose, instead? Choices:  A: walk B: change shoes C: play tag D: smell smoke E: reach over<n><n>### Response:		Smell Smoke<n><n>### Motivation<n>I do enjoy your work and appreciate that you shared it with us. <n>Your responses are insightful.  You provided details and supporting data. The choice 'A: walk', is not related to boredom, because boring is an adjective describing a feeling, and a subject performing the action. This choice can be removed or left blank without affecting the problem. The choice 'D: smell smoke' is the most straightforward and it captures your insight that children act out. The other choice answers are too vague. For instance, if a child 'changes shoes', what is she thinking about?  I think it's funny to see it stated like this, but it seems that 'walk to get bored' might be more related to the choice than 'change shoes'.<n><n>### Follow-up: You made 1 grammatical errors. Correct 5 of the errors and provide explanations for what was incorrect. Examples: The dog is at the park (incorrect: use a singular verb; the dog is running across the park; The dog is running across the field; The dog is going to the park; The dog and its tail are in the park)<n><n>### Response<n>1.) The dog is at the Park The dog is at the dog park The dog is running around the dog park The dog was at the dog park before it ran around The dog is sleeping at the dog park<n>2.) The dog and its tail is at the dog park<n><n>3.) The dog is at is tail at the dog park The Dog is at its tail at the dog park<n>The dog at is tail at the Dog Park The dog park is at the dog's tail at the dog park

Choices:  A: train station B: house C: cupboard D: cricket stadium E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input :What is the average distance a jogger runs with 1 run per day?<n><n>### Response :F<n><n>### Input  :An investor has 60,000 dollars invested. 6% of the principal is payed on a yearly basis. Answer the multiple choice question.<n>It was a night of stars, and they were the shiniest ones I have ever seen. The question will ask me to write down all the numbers of the minute hand that fall between 9:30 and 16:30. How can I improve the efficiency of my search? I want to spend as little time as possible on this practice.<n><n>### Output:"I can use a timer to time myself. I can also make two search sets.  After typing the numbers of the minute hands from 9:30 to 10:30, I can write down the next 5 numbers from 30 minutes.  Write 5 numbers per 5 seconds. Do not start numbering until the minute hand is 40 minutes. You can record the next 5 numbers for the whole clock.<n>

He walks back up to the register where he paid and sees the total cost of $40 but then looks below the register and sees an additional charge of $5 to be applied to all sales under $100. The shirt was priced at $13. What should he pay to complete the transaction?<n>Answer: $45 - 4.5 = $40.5<n><n>> NOTE: You can test your solution using the below link<n><n>https://repl.it/@jomir40<n><n>**Input:**<n><n>Input: Ian buys a shirt, priced at $15, and a pair of shoe, priced at $34. He walks back to the register where he bought the shirt and sees the total cost was $49. There is an additional charge of 6 to be applied to all purchases under $100, but the shirt was actually priced at $20. What should Ian pay to complete the transaction<n><n>> NOTE : You can test your solution at here<n><n>https://replit.com/@Jomir40/Food-Bank-195<n><n>###<n>

Choices:  A: hatred B: surprised C: compliments D: dedication E: solutions<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I think the answer is C: compliments<n><n>### Explaination:<n><n>### The input is, "Every great person is good at something." How does it follow that "hatred" "and solutions" is a way to achieve it? They are all negative thoughts.<n><n>### Every good person achieves success by complimenting those around them and by getting compliments from other people. Complimenting those around you will make them good at something because of the encouragement you give those people. <n><n>### Lack of dedication does not lead to greatness like I thought it may. Lack of solutions may help if a company or organization has a problem, but not for an individual.<n><n>### Dedication must be earned, so it's not required for a great person. Compliments must be given, though, and solutions must be solved to become great. That leaves me with compliments. I hope I'm right, but I think I'm right.<n>

Choices:  A: confusion B: complications C: riot D: arrest E: protests<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Explanation:<n>The correct answer is the only one that does not refer to criminal action (C). Riots (B) and protests (E) are instances of civil behavior whereas arrests (D) are part of criminal proceedings. Civil institute (A) means to bring about civil proceedings such as lawsuits, judicial tribunals, etc.<n><n>### Input<n>:What factors are necessary for a successful democracy?<n><n>### Response<n>:Citizen participation, freedom of beliefs and practices.<n><n>### Explination<n><n>The correct answer contains more than one necessary factor, "freedom of beliefs and practices". Other possible answers, which are not on the list but should be, are "tolerance" and "individual freedom".<n><n>### Input <n>:The cost of living rose by 7% last month.<n><n>### Response <n>:It was 10% last year.<n><n>### Explain <n><n>The correct answer is based only on general trends. It can only predict the situation at the end of a year. <n><n>### Input : <n>Find the common factor among 45, 60, 78<n><n>### Response : <n>The common factor is 1<n><n>### Explantion :<n><n>Since none of these numbers is divisible by 2, 3, or 5, their common factors must be 1 and/or -1. <n>

For example, if the input is 12, it means that your vehicle has 12 horsepower.<n>* The second input is an integer value that will be the width, height, and width of your antigravity car. For example, if your width is 6 meters, height is 5 meters, and its length is 2.5 meters, you would input 6:5:2.5.<n>* The third input will be an integer value. The input will be the volume of empty space in the cockpit. For example, if there is 5 square feet of available space in the cockpot, you would input 10.<n>* The fourth string input to the program will be the name of the location that you would like the antigravity vehicle to be kept during its lifetime or flight.

Choices:  A: utah B: south america C: new hampshire D: japan E: new mexico<n><n>### Response:		The answer is A; Utah.<n><n>Languages are used for communication between humans. New Hampshire is an American state whereas Japan is a country in Asia. Similarly, Utah is an American state, but New Mexico is a state that neighbors Utah.<n><n>The last option on the list is South America. There are 17 countries in South America.<n><n>### InputAnswers.csv<n><n>The data below describes two players named George and Mike, and the basketball team they play for. There are four columns, the name of the column and what the value means. Use the information to answer the questions that follow.<n><n>Column 1: Team<n>Column 2: George's age<n>Column 3: Mike's age<n>Column George's goals per game<n>Column Michael's points per game<n><n>George scores three goals. He scores two goals more than a player named Mike, who scores one goal. <n><n>**Q:**  Who scored more goals? <n><n>**A:** Mike. <n><n>**L:** George is 20 years old. Mike is 25 years old.<n><n>**Q:  Find the difference**<n><n>**A: 5**<n><n>George and Mike both play for the same basketball team. The team's average points per game is three. George's average goals per game is three. <n><n>**A.**  George is three times better at goals than the team average.  What's the best George has ever scored in two games? <n><n>**B.**  By comparing George's current age to Michael's current age, find Michael's average. <n><n>**C.**  By comparing Mike's current age to George, Mike's best two game average is higher than George. If George averages three goals per game for his team, and Mike's best two games average two times that, what is George's average goal? <n><n>**D.**  Use the difference you found in the previous question to estimate how many goals George is three times better.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Sarah opened his chest and found a second heart.  Her patient might not be what? Choices:  A: istanbul B: animal C: antique shop D: human being E: bedroom<n><n>### Response:		Istanbul<n><n>### InputA:  A: b B: b C: b D: b E: b<n><n>### ResponseA: b<n><n>## Instructions:Your answer should correspond to a line of code in one the two languages.<n><n>### Question:What is the correct method to convert 100% to a float, assuming that the function contains the following lines?<n><n>```python<n>numToConvert = 100<n>numToConvert2 = numToConvert + numToConvert<n><n>print("The original number is", numToConvert)<n>print("The additional number is", numToConvert2)<n><n>fNumber = float (numToConvert + numToToConvert2)<n><n>print("The floating point number is",fNumber) <n>```<n><n>### Response1:  print("The floating point number", fNumber)<n><n>### Response2:  print("The resulting floating point number is", float(numToConvert + numTotoConvert2))<n><n>## Input:The given function does not print results. You should replace "print" with "print (", a parenthesis, and ")", a closing parenthesis.<n><n>### Responsea:The original number is 100The additional number is 101fNumber = float(101 + 101)print("The resulting floating point", fNumber)<n>

What is the probability each number is chosen in a random sample of 10 numbers? 2. It takes two trials to get a sample of 10, one for each number. 3. It takes three trials to get a trial in our sample. 4. What is the probability the sample will contain the number 3?<n><n>### Solution:1. The first way it relates is that each number has a probability 0.1 and the sample has 10 numbers. 2. That is not possible for two trials 3. Choices:  A: veldt B: ocean C: savannah D: africa E: jungle<n><n>### Response:		Where does a lion live?<n><n>### Instructions:Answer each question.<n><n>## Instructions :<n><n>```java<n>import java.util.Scanner;<n><n>public class AoPS<n>{<n>  private static  Scanner scanner;<n><n>  public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception<n>  {<n>    scanner = new Scanner(System.in);<n>    int n = scanner.nextInt();<n>    scanner.nextLine();<n>    System.out.println(n);<n>    int triviaNum=0;<n>    while (true)<n>    {<n>      System.out.println("\n[1]Trivia(Next Question)\n[2]Exit\n");<n>      Integer choice=scanner.nextInt();         <n>      if(choice==2)<n>      {<n>        return;<n>      }<n>      String input = scanner.nextLine().toLowerCase();<n>      String answer=null;<n><n>      if( ( (triviaNum+1)%scanner.nextInt()==0 )&& scanner.nextInt()!=scanner.nextInt())<n>      {<n>        answer=scanner.nextLine();   <n> <n>      }<n><n>      if (input.equalsIgnoreCase("[2]Exit"))<n>      {<n>        System.out.println("Thanks for trying.");<n>        break;<n>      }<n><n><n>      String[] split=(input.split("\\s+"));<n>      if ( split[1].equalsIgnoreCase("[1]Triva"))<n>      {<n> <n><n>        if ( ( (triviaNumber)%scanner. nextInt()==0 ) ? true : false)<n>        {<n>       answer=scanner. nextLine();      //Above answer<n>       triviaNumber+=1;<n>       System.out.println ("Correct ");<n>         }<n>         else<n>            {<n><n>                System.out.println ( "Incorrect");<n>            }<n>        }<n>        else<n>        {<n>           System.out.println "";<n>       }  <n><n>      triviaNum++;<n>       scanner.nextLine ( );<n>       }<n>        }<n>```<n><n>

Print out the value 1000 with `console.log()`.<n>The value after the `console.log()` function must not be modified in any way.<n><n>### Challenge<n>Use the code below to calculate a price for the total amount of groceries and for each item that are bought at a certain store. The total cost of items should correspond to the cost of groceries. The total cost of the items should be printed out after the second console.log() call. The `store` function should be called twice, once with each argument and it should return cost for each of those items.<n><n>### Question<n>Suppose you have to write a `store(item, cost)` called function. What will be the parameter names for calling the function?<n><n>```javascript<n>function store(item, cost) {<n>  console.log(item);<n>  console.log("This object was updated");<n>  return cost;<n>}<n>store("Bananas", 3);<n>store.store("Apples", 6);<n>```<n><n>### Solution<n>What would you expect to see printed after the calls to the `store()`?<n><n>```javascript store(Bananas, 3.75)<n>```<n>

She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:John is a human who is in a wheelchair due to an accident. On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Where are a lot of offices in New York? Choices:  A: school building B: skyscraper C: business D: grocery store. E: work<n><n>### Response:		<n>A <n>C <n>E<n><n><n>### Feel free to use any built-in libraries or packages you want. <n><n><n>### Challenge<n><n>There are 1,000 marbles in a jar. Each ball bear a number from 1 to 1,00. The grips is drawn, pick a marble, replace it into the jar and put another marble to the top of the jar. Draw again, keep doing this for every draw except the last which will keep drawing until you are unable to pick a ball. Compute the chance that all the numbers from 1 to 999 will appear once or more.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Let X be the number of balls that appear at least once. <n><n>For every draw, there are at most two possibilities:<n>* The last drawn ball is in the top 100<n>* The last drawn marble is in the top 999<n><n>There are 999 balls at least once (from X=1 to X=999). The probability is therefore:<n><n>1 / 1,00,000*1,000<n><n>### Example Input<n><n>Input: 2<n><n><n>### Solution:<n><n>1 / (999! + 999)<n><n>

Choices:  A: love B: zoo C: school D: space shuttle E: library<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiplechoice question.<n><n><n>### Response :<n><n>```<n><n>### Outputs:<n><n><n><n>```<n><n>Input:How much does 5 kilograms of carrots cost?<n>Answer:$0.20<n><n>Input:How many hours did it take to fill a truck with a 38,000 stone capacity?<n>Answer:$0<n><n>Input:What is 7000 times 10?<n>Answer:$240,000<n><n>Input:"5 12-ounce cans of soda" is how many ounces of soda?<n>Answer:120<n><n>Input:"250 blocks" is how may?<n>Answer:14<n>```<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>```Javascript<n><n>var number=0;<n>var sum = 0;<n>var num = prompt("How much does 5 kgs of carrots cost")<n>    document.getElementById("display1").innerText =num;<n>    sum = parseInt(parseFloat(num)/5)  <n><n>for(var i = 1; i<=5; i++){ <n>    document.getElementById(`display${i}`).innerText = sum;}  <n><n><n>}<n><n>document.getElementById('reset').onclick=function(){<n><n>    num = prompt("How many hours did it fill the truck, with 38,068 stone capacity").split(":").reverse().join(" ")<n><n>    number++<n>        <n>    document.getElementById('display1').innerText =num;  <n>    sum += parseInt(Number(num))<n><n> for(var i = 2; i<= number;++ i){<n>     document.getElementById(`display`+i).innerText = sum;};<n>   <n><n>}<n><n><n><n>}<n>```<n>

How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Where can you store a small notepad on your person? Challenge:<n><n>Write a function "Sum" which accepts two numbers and returns an answer of the sum of the two numbers.<n><n>The function’s purpose should be obvious, but note that you cannot use an operator (`+`, for example) in your answer.<n><n>### Challenge Solution<n>```javascript<n>// Sum<n>export default function Sum (x, y) {<n>  return x + y<n>}<n>```<n><n>In this example, the function’s name should be `Sum(x,y)`, and the function should return the sum of the passed-in parameters.<n><n>### Solution Note<n><n>For this exercise, be sure to create a single function with at least one parameter, though you may have more. <n><n>### Demo<n>```javascript<n>let hello = Sum (10, 20);<n>```<n>### Challenge:Answer the following multiple question.<n><n>## Input:Write a function "Double" that takes a number as a parameter, doubles the number, and then returns that number.<n><n>### Answer:<n>```javascript<n>function double (number) {<n>    return number * 2<n>}<n>```<n>If you write the function using arrow functions with the solution, you may just need to return the doubled number.<n><n>## Challenge: Write a function that accepts two numbers and returns their sum plus twice their product.<n>```javascript<n>function addDouble (x, y) {}<n>```<n>## Sample Usage:<n>```javascript<n>let addDouble (10, 5);<n>```<n><n>## Challenge Solution: Write a function that takes a number and returns the square root of that number<n>```javascript<n>function root (x) {<n>    return Math.sqrt(x);<n>}<n>```<n>##Demo: The sum if the challenge solutions<n>```javascript<n>let number1 = 13;<n>let number2 = 38;<n><n>let double = (number2 + (number2 * 2));<n>let squareRoot = (number1 * 10);<n>let sum = double + squareRoot;<n><n>console.log(sum);<n><n>```<n><n><n>## Challenge:Use ES6’s map() built-in function to calculate product and then add its value to the accumulator variable. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Shane was supposed to speak at his fathers funeral.  He was a clown, and acted very ridiculous.  This cheerfulness turned off people who expected the funeral to be what? Choices:  A: solemn B: compete C: serious D: somber E: straightforward<n><n>### Response:		A: solemn<n><n>## Conclusion<n>The above solution worked perfectly as expected. You may want to test other solution on your own.<n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:When a monkey is taken away from their home they are often brought to this place where people wear white coats. Choices:  A: rain forest B: research laboratory C: cage D: treetops E: south africa<n><n>### Response:		E<n>Input:When a monkey...<n>...is taken away from their home...<n>...they are often brought to this...<n>...where...<n>...in a white coat...<n>...and a cage.<n><n>### Input<n>A man is driving to New York. He makes it to Utah, and decides to spend the night. He checks into the hotel and goes to bed. Upon returning to bed, from the bathroom, he sees a man at his bedside and shouts, “Who the hell are you?” The man says “Your wife’s brother.” The man in the bed looks at the floor for a minute and screams, “Shit! And when did you get into my room?” What is the answer to this riddle?<n><n>### Response<n>A woman walks in to her barn and spots her cow and the bull she slept with. She runs away crying! Why?<n><n>The man says I’m your wife’s brother.<n><n>While the bull was in the barn!<n><n>### Input When a man is rung up for 26 cents more than change given. And given 16 cents. What is the answer to the riddle? What is the riddle/problem?<n><n>### Answer<n>The woman spotted them with 6 cents. So she pays for 20 cents and rounds up to 24 cents since the total came to 26 cents. The bartender then gives her 16 cents change for 24 cents.<n><n>### Question<n><n>### Input Why did it take the person less time to move 25 pigs than 103 pigs one way?<n><n>### Input <n>The pigs all walk at the same speed.<n><n>### Answer <n>The person took the pigs to walk in a straight line. The pigs would stop because they couldn’t see where they were going. Then the person stopped. So it took less time.<n><n>### Riddle<n><n>

How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Where did the person have to walk downstairs to get the tool? Choices:  A: hardware store B: basement C: garage D: repair shop E: the library.<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions:In the table, each box is one set consisting of number of players playing with two different cards. You have 20 players and 6 cards (number cards 1-6). You want to make an arrangement so that each set includes exactly 2 players and 1 card. Note that the number of sets = (20*6)*2! = 56. What is one arrangement?<n><n>| Card | Player 1   | Player 2   | Played Together<n>---<n>| 1   | Mark        | David      |<n>| --- | ---         | ---         |<n>| 1   + 3   | Sharon     | Daniel     |<n>| 1  | George      | Andrew     |<n>| **2** | Aubrey      | Michael    |<n>| 2** + 3** | Jennifer   | John       |<n>| 2  | Melva       | Riann      |<n>| 3  | Jillie      | Thomas     |<n>| **3** + 4** | Caitlyn   | Brian      |<n>| **3  |** Jeffery   | Sarah      |<n>| **4  |** Brandy     | Bennett    |<n><n>**2  + 3  = Card is 5**<n>

Choices:  A: cupboard B: oven C: grocery store D: pantry E: cellar<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Please describe your answer, explain any intermediate steps taken, and the final solution. For example:<n><n>I. Create a new `can` list.<n><n>II. Add a can in the first position in the `can` list. (It's `0.05 can`)<n><n>III. Set `total_price` to be 45.<n><n>IV. Iterate from 2 to 5 until I see something like 99.76. (This is an example.)<n><n>V. Now I know how much is the total price to buy 5 cans<n><n>### Subscriptions:<n>This question is answered using the data structure `List` and also the division operator.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>A `List` is basically used to hold multiple items like strings, numbers, and so much more.<n><n>### What I did:<n>1. Create a List called `can` with `0` as an element.<n>2. Add the first can price (`.05 can`) to the List.<n><n>### Result:<n>45.<n><n>### Why:<n>Because Lists are ordered in the order of their insertion, thus:<n><n>> 1. Create a List. `.05 can` is inserted into the List.<n><n>> 2. The result is `45.05 can` which is stored in `.05 can`.<n><n>### How to read data:<n>The output represents price per can of soup.<n><n>### How can I increase the efficiency of my solution:<n>More efficient ways would be to:<n><n>```<n>- Add more elements when needed<n>- Looping less<n>```<n>

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:The shark was migrating between continents, where did biologists find it? Choices:  A: backpack B: closet C: drawer D: dinner E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		Dinner<n><n><n>### Instructions:  Your response goes here.<n><n>### Inputs(What is the student inputting):<n>- Utensils (a kitchen tool/utensil)<n>- Evening activity<n>- The number of choices/choices<n>- Example: Utensils are used during dinner, which is a type of evening activity. There are five options and the answer is 3.<n>### Choices:(options)<n>- A: backpack<n>- B: closet<n>- C: drawer<n>- D: dinner<n>- E: cupboard.<n><n>### Output<n>#### Example of output:(answer)<n>Option A is incorrect.<n>Option B is correct.<n>Option C is correct.<n>Option D is incorrect.<n>Option E is incorrect.<n>Total: 2<n><n>### Input Format <n>#### Utensils     (Input to the command)<n>> The first input would be something like “A: backpack”    <n><n>#### evening activity    (Input to the command in the function)<n>> The second input would be the name of the weekday (Ex. Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday etc)<n><n>### Output Format   <n>#### options       (What the function/command outputs)<n>> The user will need to specify how many choices there are, and each option should be a word not a string.<n>- The name of the weekday.<n><n>#### Total    (output to the function/command)<n>> The last thing the user would to do is type the total number of options.<n><n>### Notes<n>- The number of options the user provides needs to be the same as how many you input into the code.<n>- If you have the number of choices set to five, you must type out the first five options in sequence.<n>- The output must say “Options 1 through x of 5.” or “Total: 5”.<n>- If a user enters one letter, you should let them re-enter.<n><n><n><n># Task Example 1.<n>Input: Adam bought two kilograms of raisins and two kilograms of pears at a store. Three kilograms of raidins cost $18 and two kilograms cost $10. How much did his purchase cost?<n>Answer: ($36) <n><n># Task Example2.<n>Input: The

Choices:  A: friendship B: aggression C: defeat D: winning or losing E: sweat<n><n>### Response:		Explanation: A.Friendship.  I have gone through all the options and it does not take away the word from meaning "friendship.  The last statement also states that this is how they work.  This is not really a competing of defeating or winning.  It is competing to work against one another.  It is competitive and is a little bit of a friendly competition.  Competitive competition and friendly competition can only come from one place, a place of friendship.<n><n>### Validate your response: I looked through options B - D and I do not see it meaning "friendship".  B stands for aggression.  C stands for defeat and E stands for sweat. The context of the statement does not allow for any of them to work.  I can even see that D and E are directly to the point of the statement "competitive competition and friendly competition".  It does not support that the answer to the question is E.<n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:What is a fast but expensive way to send small cargo? Choices:  A: airplane B: ship's hold C: boat D: truck E: train<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>* A: airplane A: fast but expensive<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>1. Write the line that answers the given question.<n>2. Input and return the correct variable for the given expression.<n>3. Input and multiply any two real numbers and return the product.<n>4. Check for type.<n>5. Include only the line containing the return statement.<n>6. Comment your code.<n>7. You will be graded on your solution's clarity, completeness, and correctness.<n><n>---<n>### Input:<n>A new employee has requested to use his benefits immediately instead of waiting until the next pay period. How many hours will be skipped if 48 hours is the normal pay period and the benefits allowance is 48 hours/pay period?<n><n>### Output:<n>48 hour/pay period / 2 = 24<n><n>### Response<n>A,<n>D,<n>E,<n>### Instruction:<n>For the above input-output, what is your output? Choices:  A: switzerland B: pennsylvania C: picture D: asia E: austria<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: E.<n><n>### Answer Explanation:<n>First, read the question carefully. The first sentence contains "an eastern state" which is why it should not be Pennsylvania (unless you take out the "an" and make it "the"). Because the second sentence is about a mountain, and picture and D don't have mountains, that leaves you with Asia and Austria, making "E" the correct response<n>

If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:If I need deodorant, where do I go to but some? Choices:  A: medicine cabinet B: medicine chest C: armpits D: grocery store E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		A

Choices:  A: restorand B: wedding party C: church basement D: corridor E: restaurant<n><n>### Response:		The answer is option "E": restaurant<n><n><n># Challenge task:<n>1) The name of the dog, of type {breed: dog breed, owner: owner}, given the name of the dog and its breed is the owner (i.e. its owner is its owner).<n><n><n>2) Find the name of the owner of the dog above<n><n><n>3) The owner of this dog is not its owner.<n><n><n>4) Do not assume the dog is a type of other dogs, and vice versa. For example, if the name of the dog is "Husky", and the breed of the dog is "Dalmation" you cannot say that a Husky is a Dalmation.<n><n><n>5) In each example below, show if the dog is a Dalmation or not. In the end, there should be five statements, one statement should say (True/False) Dalmation, the other four should state if the given example is a Dalmation (Yes/No, or Nothing (is not a Dalmation).<n><n><n>Input: Do not assume the dog above is a Dalmation<n><n>Input: The dog above is a Dalmatian<n><n>Input: I will assume a Dalmation is a dog<n><n><n><n><img src="https://github.com/mrdoob/three.js/blob/master/examples/images/kinect_points.png" height="300" width="300"><img src="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Dalmatian.jpg/240px-Dalmatian.jpgg" height="307" width="307"><img src="https:/" height="100" width="100"><img height="100%" width="100%" src="http://upload.wikimedia/wikipedia/commons/b/bb/Sitting_dog2.jpg"><n><n><n># Solution:<n>- Find a way to make an if statement conditionally add the names of a dog's owner to a new list, depending on whether the dog and the potential owner share a common breed.<n>- Create a nested if else statement, where the potential owner of a dog is returned if the dog's owner name is identical to the name of the

Which of the following is the least amount of days Kamal plays video games? Choice A: 3 days B: 4 days C: 5 days D: 6 days<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input <n>Romeo eats breakfast every weekday morning. How many breakfasts did Romeo eat last week? Choice A: Monday-Friday 20 breakfasts B: 11 breakfasts C: 10 breakfasts D: 7 breakfasts<n><n>### Response <n><n>### Input (Demonstration)A man drives a car to a local gas station to fill up. If the man bought 3 gallons of regular and 2 gallons of premium gas, how much did he spend filling up?<n><n>### Note:Answers will vary based on whether you are using a metric or imperial system.  Choose an answer based on where you live.  (Choices:  A: 8 gallons / $16<n><n>### Response (Demonstration)[1]. A is correct because the man bought 3 regular and 5 premium.  [2]. A is close, but since regular is more expensive, we will spend more of our budget on it and less of it on premium.  ([3]. B is correct because we use the gas prices from the first demonstration.  [4]. B is correct because the two tanks are of different size, 9 gallon regular vs 12 gallon premium. You can also do this:  If he bought 3 regular and premium and spent $10, the costs for each gallon would be $3.33.  If he bought 12 premium and 9 regular then the costs for each gallion would be $3.63.  $10/3.33 is the cheaper cost per gallon, $10/3 is the more expensive cost per gallon.  Choice A is when the regular and premium amounts are the same, choice C is when the premium and regular amounts are the same, and choice B is when their difference is bigger than their cost per gallon.<n><n>### Input A:The number of apples in a

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Where would you buy a ticket to sit in a room with a lot of chairs facing the same direction? A candy store is an establishment that sell candies.  The post office is an establishment that sits on counter to sell letter. An auto repair shop is an establishment that only repairs automobile. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:The police man was waving flares, what did he do with the impatient car? Write the answer at the bottom of the page in pencil.<n><n>### Question 1:<n>Which is the best description of the process of science?<n><n>    1. scientists always agree on the findings of an experiment<n><n>    2. people who do not have scientific training may have opinions on science<n><n>    3. it is a process that is always in doubt<n><n>    4. it is an opinion that people may change their minds about<n><n>Which term correctly describes the law of conservation of energy?<n>    1. energy is never lost permanently<n><n>    2. energy is never created<n><n>    3. when energy is used, an equal amount is produced<n><n>    4. energy is the most valuable resource in the world<n><n>Which of the following is scientifically accurate?<n>    1. the universe is 40,000 square miles<n><n>    2. Jupiter is the planet<n><n>    3. birds are warm-blooded organisms<n><n>    4. the earth revolves around the sun<n><n>What are the two main parts of the life cycle of most viruses?<n><n>    1) infection/symptoms<n><n>    2) virus/replication<n><n>    3) transmission/immunity<n><n>    4) spread/eradication<n><n>Microorganisms are so small that in order to see them, they must be magnified. What does this tell scientists?<n><n>    1: microbes have never been able to reproduce to fill Earth's surface and atmosphere<n><n>    2. a microscope allows them to see the microbes<n><n>    3. not all microbes are related to other organisms<n><n>    3. microbes can grow easily in the human body<n><n>Which statement do you most agree with about Darwin's theory of evolution?<n><n>    1 The Earth is a place of continuous change and progress.<n><n>    2. Nothing in nature is irreplaceable <n><n>    3. Living things that adapt have a greater chance of surviving than those that do not.

Choices:  A: ghost town B: third world country C: human body D: rug E: hospital<n><n>### Response:		<n>```text<n>E. the Hospital, because there are many people and all of them interact with patients<n><n>or<n><n>D. the rug, because bacteria love to live there<n><n>or<n><n>A. a ghost town, because there is no humans to spread disease<n><n>or<n><n>B. a third world country, because of sanitation issues<n><n>or<n><n>C. the human body, because people travel to and from 3rd world countries<n>```<n>### Input:Which should you not feed a dog? Choices:  X: dog bones Y: raw meat Z: raw fruits and vegetables B: cottage cheese<n><n>### Response<n>```text<n>Z. raw fruits and vegetable, because they are not processed or cook, the bacteria might be in  the food.<n><n>or<n><n>X. dog bones, because bacteria may get in there and the bones are not processed or cook.<n>```<n><n>### Input : The population of a city has grown by 100 people every two years, so it has increased by more than half of what it was in fifty years time. What was the population at the beginning?<n>### Demo :<n>```text<n>100+100=200, 200+102=302, 302+102...<n>therefore 50(years time)*100(people added to population)=25000<n>25000*100(people)/2(years)=125000 people<n>```<n>### Response :<n>```text<n>The population at the beginning was 12500<n><n>OR<n><n>2500(year 1)+100+15000(year 50)=100<n>0.100(year1)=100<n>180000*(100/200)=100 <n>100×(100/100)=1<n><n>OR<n><n>If 0.5 were added to each year instead, 180,000 would be the population at the beginning<n>```<n><n>## Author: [Bill Ocampo](https://github.com/obillcampo)<n>

Choices:  A: picnic basket B: wine press C: juice D: fruit cocktail E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n><n>Fruit cocktails make use of a mix of grapes. They are used to give flavour to fruit cocktails, a cocktail which is a mix of fruit juice. They are also commonly sold in juice bottles, where a variety of fruit juices are sold. This is done to make the juice affordable to the customer. The variety of juices allows the person buying the juice the opportunity to choose the flavour that they like most.<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>Mother Teresa was born in 1910 and died in 1997. He was born on 26 August 1910 (her nationality was Albanian) in the former Yugoslavia. He gained worldwide recognition through her work in helping the less fortunate, especially through her work with the destitute in India. This made her the first to be called in the history of the world as "Mother."<n><n><n>### Response<n><n>Her most significant contribution to mankind was the creation of the "Mother Teresa's Missionaries of Charity." This was aimed at helping the needy. Her work in the 1940s was mainly targeted towards patients in medical facilities, but as the year went by, the organization expanded and began looking for the destitute. The organization's activities include helping the poor and needy around the world in various ways. This includes, among others, providing food for the hungry, shelter for the homeless, counselling for the sick, and education for the underprivileged.<n><n>The organization was first established in India in 1950. This was done after Mother Teresa visited the city of Calcutta. This was after she was moved by the poorest of the poor living conditions in the city. This event was a turning point in Mother Teresa's life. This was because she had decided for the first time in her life to dedicate herself completely to the service of the people. In 1982, she received the Nobel Peace prize because of her many efforts through the organization.<n><n><n>## Question 6<n><n>### Input :<n><n>Bill is a math teacher who earns $35 an hour. Every year, he gets a raise of $2 an hour. How much does Bill earn each year as he gets ra

How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:In war, your primary method is combat, but your goal is to do what? Choices:  A: conquer opponent B: fight enemy C: join army D: kill E: terrible<n><n>### Response:		Your primary method is combat, and your goal is to fight your enemy.<n>### Justification:<n><n>### Input<n>|Description|Type|Value|<n>|---|---|---|<n>|Primary Method|Noun|Combat|<n>|Your primary method is combat.|Declarative Phrase|Primary Method, Your primary method is combat|<n><n>### Output<n>|Description|Type<n>|---|---<n>|Goal|Noun|Fight<n>|Your goal is to fight.|Declarative|The goal, Your goal is to combat|<n><n>## Solutions<n><n>### Input#answer<n>The primary method was combat and the goal was fight.<n><n>### Input #1<n>The method that she used to fill up the truck was combat and her goal was fight.<n>

In 2031, 21.5% of the population will be at least 65 years old, and over the following ten years the proportion of people aged 65 and older will rise from 18.6% to 20.4%. Choices:  A: shoes B: wet ground C: wet clothes D: start to fall E: water garden<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer choice is D: start to fall. You should avoid it.<n><n>### Response:"Halfway to heaven"<n>We suggest that you don't check this place out. The name itself sounds a little too good to be true.

If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Billy's mother tripped over a stuffed animal.  She yelled at him not to leave his things where? Choices:  A: toy store B: hall C: bathroom D: amusement park E: fairgrounds<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input:(Asked at the end of the test)<n>There are two cash cows, Boss 1 and Boss 2, at a company who wants to put a cow on a deserted island. ") #Get message printing<n><n>#Function to check whether the given number is a multiple of 2<n>def is_divisible by_two( numb ):<n>	if numb == 0 or numb == 1:<n>		print("Divisible by 2")<n>    	else:<n>		print ("Not dividebale by 2")<n>#Function to check if a number is odd or even<n>def is_odd( numb ):     <n>	odd = 0;	<n>	if numb % 2 == 1:<n>                	odd = 1;<n>    	return odd<n><n>def coffee():<n>#This is the main script for coffee function<n>    total_q   = 0<n>    total_price = 0<n>    print("This is the Main Function to check how many kg of coffee to enter")<n>    #Check whether Coffee is entered<n>    if input("Give Quant Coffee : ") == "":<n>    	print("Missing Option Please give the quantities again")<n>    else:<n>             while(input("Give

Choices: A:  coffee,  B: throw up,  C: food, D: getting drunk, E: wine <n><n>### **Instruction:** Write a short program that determines whether the provided statement is true or false.<n>If its true, output true. If its false, output false.<n><n>### **Demonstration:**<n><n><n>#### How do we complete this task?<n>Write a sentence to start the process, then write a question to end the sentence, then write the answer to the question.<n><n>## Output: <n>What might Brad drink?<n><n>True<n><n>#### How do you know its true?<n>If you answer a question, ask it again and be surprised by the answer.<n><n>## Error Explanation:<n>If you answer question, do not answer it a third time, or ask it again, you will get an error.<n>

Fuel prices also went up by 20%. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Sammy wanted to go to where the people were.  Where might he go? Choices:  A: race track B: populated areas C: the desert D: apartment E: roadblock<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n><n>### Instructon:<n>Describe, without showing, how an algorithm that reads text should process a string.<n><n>### Example 1: The following line of text represents a single input value read by the algorithm.<n><n>###  Example 2: Following is a piece of input to be passed to the algorithm.<n><n>Output:  <n><n>### Response to Example 1 (A)<n><n>```<n>while (i < length) {<n>    if (s[i] == 'a') {<n>        if (a.e)<n>            a.end = s[i];<n>        i++;<n>    } else if (s[i].l == true) { // line break<n>        a = {t: s[i], e: s[i + 1], l: true}; // add line break<n>        i += 2; // skip over newline<n>    } else {<n>        if (s[i]) {<n>            if (s[i - 1].l == true) a.p = s[i - 1];<n>            s[i - 2] = s[i -1];<n>            i -= 2;<n>            a.t = s[i]; // add text<n>        } else {<n>            a.t += "A";<n>        }<n>    }<n>    }<n>```<n><n>>### Response to Example2 (B)<n><n>```<n>var text = "I am a spoon. I am a fork. I am a spoon. And I am a fork.";<n>```

How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:What home entertainment equipment requires cable? Choices:  A: radio shack B: substation C: cabinet D: television E: desk<n><n>### Response:		Television or computer (C and E)<n><n>Output:<n><n>1) (A,C) radio shack and cabinet;<n>2) (B,E) substation and radio shack;<n>3) (D,A) desk and cabinet;<n>4) (E,B) television and radio shack; 5) (D,E) desk and television; <n>6) (C,A) cabinet and radio shack; and<n>7) (D,E,B) computer, television and radio cabinet<n><n>Output:<n>```<n>A: radio shack<n><n>B: substation<n><n>C: cabinet<n><n>D: television<n>    E: desk<n>```<n>Output:<n>```javascript<n>const answer = ["cabinet","substation","cabinet","desk","cabinet","radio shack","television", "radio shack","desk","cable,"<n>    "either","tv","desk","radio shack","a","b","d","c","d","e"].join(" ");<n>```<n>The script below is the algorithm.<n><n>```javascript<n>let answer = ["cabinettv","desktvradio shack tv","radio shack desktv","desk radio shack tv","radiocabinettv"];<n>```<n>The question has three parts.<n>1) (A) What home entertainment equipment does not require cable? (Answer: Radio shack or cabinet)<n>2) (B) What home entertainment requires cable? (Answer: Television or computer)<n>3) (C to E) For each pair (A,B), show every possible combination that is a valid answer to the question. How many combinations are there in A and B pair?<n><n>The third part has six combinations.<n><n>1-2 combinations are radio shack and cabinet and desk and television.<n><n>3-4 combinations are substation and radio shacks television and desk.<n><n>5-6 combinations are cabinet and desk and desk and radio shack and radio shack television.<n><n>### Output: What are the best answers?<n><n>The script below shows combinations.<n><n>```javascript(JavaScript)<n>input = ["radio shack","cabinet", "substation","radio shack"]<n><n>let output = ["radio shack cabinet", "radio shack substation

How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:What type of person typically contracts illness? If he walked for a while and then took a break, the sunshine would not have made the surface hot on hi feet.  But if he was walking, then the surface was warm from the solar heating. <n>

B.August is not a verb, it’s a month. C.Dispare means to separate. D.Make larger doesn’t even make sense. E.Expand isn’t a verb, so it’s not even an option.<n><n>### Input<n>> The number of goals scored by each of the 22 players in a team that took the field was chosen randomly. A new position also was chosen randomly that accounted for 20% to be a forward, 20% to middle, and the remaining 60% to be back.  How many of each position were on the field?<n><n>### Response<n>```python<n>def func(players): <n>    return (len([x for x in players if x["Position"] == "goal"]), len([x for x in <n>    players if x["Position" == "middle"]]), len([x for x i playes if x["Position"== "back"]]))<n>```<n><n>Input<n>> John, Paul, George and Ringo are each friends of your aunt’s. Each member of your family has either the same or a different birthday. Your cousin celebrates on the 9th day of the month.  Which day celebrates John Paul George and Ringo?<n><n>### Input A<n><n>In the string “The quick brown dog jumps over the lazy cat”, what is the value of the letter X? X could stand for any character.<n><n>### Response A<n>```python<n>def readLetters(string):<n>    i = 0<n>    while i < string.lenght:<n>        print(string[i], end=" ")<n>        i+=1<n>    <n>    return<n>```<n>### Output A<n>> The quick brown dog jumps. <n><n>### Input B<n><n>Write a function named ‘square’ with input that is a positive integer and output that is its square.<n><n>### Output<n>```python<n>def square(x):<n>    x * x<n>```<n>### Response B<n><n>### Input C<n><n>Ask the user to enter a number. The program should print the number in binary and decimal format.<n><n>### Binary Format<n>```<n>[enter number]<n>>>> print

Choices:  A: demonstration B: conference C: building D: garage E: mouth<n><n>### Response:		Answer: E<n><n>### Explanation:The correct answer is "E". The text contains a spelling mistake in the choice.<n><n>### InputExamples:<n>Answer: 5310<n><n>Answer: 31<n><n>Answer: 6820<n><n>Answer:912<n><n>Answer: 16640<n><n>Answer:300<n><n>Answer:840<n><n>### OutputExamples:<n>Answer is: E<n>Answer: E<n>Answer: B<n>Answer: D<n>Answer: A<n>Answer: F<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Solution:<n>```python<n>sentence = 'A person lived in my '<n><n>def solution(sentence):<n>    words_list = sentence.split()<n><n>    for word in words_list:<n>        if word =='mouth':<n>            return word<n><n>    return 'none'<n><n>```<n>

She thought that there was more string on the spool, but it slipped out of her fingers when she reached the what?. Choices:  A: child's hand B: the last straw C: hobby shop D: end of line E: toy store<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>This can be solved using the following logic. First, we would need to determine which of the letters in the answer choices are vowels and which are consonants. If we examine the spelling at the end of "last" it tells us that it is made up of the letters "st", and if we check, we can see that these letters are vowels. From the letters that we're left with we can see that the choices contain 1 consonant (C) and 3 vowels (A, E, and I) so we know that choice E is the correct answer.<n>

Choices:  A: disorientation B: due to C: meeting new people D: getting somewhere E: relocation<n><n>### Response:		Due to<n><n>### Instructions:What is the correct answer to the above?<n><n>### Responses:<n><n>Due to<n>Due to<n><n><n><n>### Instrument Review<n><n>Check your work before moving on.<n><n><n><n>## Programming Assignment<n><n>##### Write a program that determines if a collection of dates is unreliable. Input is a list of dates, and input/output can be written to a file named input.dat for practice.<n><n>##### Code: Write the full code in a new file named "Date_Detection.cs."<n><n>##### Input<n><n>```<n>2018-06-07<n>20180608<n>2018.06.9<n>2018/10/9<n>```<n><n>##### Outlook<n><n>```<n>Invalid Input<n>```<n><n>#### Validate<n><n>```<n>25<n>```<n><n>#### Output<n><n>```<n>18.06-20.06<n>```<n><n><n>###### Programming Structure<n><n>##### Functions<n><n>```C#<n>public class DateDetection<n>{<n>  public bool UnreliableDate(IEnumerable<string> dates)<n>  {<n>    string[] invalidStartDates = new []{'/', '.', '01/'};<n>    string[] invalidEndDates = new [1]{'30/'};<n><n>    Console.WriteLine("\nInvalid Start Dates: "+invalidStartDates[0]);<n>    Console.WriteLine("Invalid End Dates: "+invalidEndDates[0]); // 1 index since 0 is reserved<n>    foreach (string date in dates)<n>    {<n>      string[] splitDate = date.Split('.');<n>      if (splitDate[0].IndexOf(invalidStartDates[1]) >=0)<n>      {<n>        Console.WriteLine("Cannot detect " + date);<n>        return true;<n>      }<n>      <n>      else if (splitDate[2].IndexOf(invalidEndDates[1]) < 1)<n>      {<n><n>        Console.WriteLine(date);<n>        return true<n>      }<n>       else<n>      {<n>        return false;<n>      }<n>    }<n>  }<n><n>  public static string FormatDate
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. Choices:  A: wedding B: tennis C: closet D: left foot E: house<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Explanation<n><n><n>```javascript<n>const num = 4236<n>const choice = parseInt(prompt(),10)<n>```<n><n>[`prompt`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/prompt) returns a string<n>[`parseInt`](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/javascript/reference/parserint/) is a<n>JavaScript method<n><n><n>```javascript  <n>if (choice > num) {<n>    showAnswer(prompt(`Where must one wear a <n>    white shoe? Choose a number between ${num} and ${num + 3}`))<n>} else if (choice < num) {<n>    console.log(`That is not in the possible range between ${num} and <n>    ${num+3}. Answer: ${choice}`)<n>} else if ( choice >= 3 && choice <= 4){<n>    console.log("The answer is: ${choice}")<n>} else {<n>    console.clear()<n>    console.log(showAnswer(prompt(`Answer: ${choice}`), num))<n>}<n>```<n><n>The above code can be simplified to<n><n><n>```javascript <n><n>```<n><n>It is an important method because it allows us to compare strings and numbers.<n>More details can be found [here](https://developer.mozilla<n><n>### Input<n><n>### Demostration<n>**Input 1: Adam bought 3  kilograms of nut  and 2. 5 kilograms of dry fruit at a store. one kilogram of nut costs 1 2 ano one kilogram of drier fruit coats 8  how much did his purchases costs  answer 56**<n>```js<n>const num = 12<n>const choice = parseFloat(prompt(),1)<n>console.log(`The nume: ${num} is: ${choice}`) <n>```<n><n><n><n>### Instructions<n>There will be 8 math inquiries and a final quiz. For example number 1 is two more than number 2, number 2 is two more than number price. Choices: 76, 77, 79, 81, 83<n><n>### Response There are 80<n><n>### Instructions:Choose the question that can complete the statement.<n><n>#### Option A: the sum is smaller than zero, the sum of minus one that will make the sum is positive.<n>#### Option B: the sum is not smaller than zero, the same sum plus two will make the sum is not negative<n><n>#### Option A would be the correct answer, the answer to Option B is false<n><n>#### Option A the sum is smaller than 0 but only if the sum is minus one makes it a positive, and in Option B makes it negative.<n><n>#### Option B could have done it<n><n>#### Option D is not a true statement because two does not make the same sum<n><n>#### Option D<n><n>

How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:John enjoyed his time visiting the museum.  He wanted to spend more time there, so that he could study the exhibits more. Choices:  A: bite B: lie down C: keep alive D: need to eat E: go to sleep<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Instructions:<n>##### The following sentence has four blanks, each representing a missing word.  Choose the correct word for each blank and write all the words on a piece of paper, then write the correct number of the words in each blank in the blank corresponding to your chosen word on each line.  Finally, write the correct number of words in each blank on a separate piece of paper after you finish.<n>##### Example:<n>If the dog 750, he will 751 up.<n>If the dog is hungry, he will lie down.<n>###### 754 to make a new list.<n>755 then, write how many words you picked a piece of paper.<n>756 your work to the teacher.<n><n>### Input for Blank 1:<n>Dolphin<n>Rabid<n>Ideal<n>Thunder<n><n>### Response for Blank 1(Word Choices):<n>Rabid (2) Thunder (1)<n><n>### Input to blank 2<n><n>Science<n>Elephant<n>Meter<n>Lost<n><n>### Response to blank 2<n>Elephant (1) Lost (2)<n><n>### Instrument 3<n>##### 1. If the dog 760, he will 860 bite.<n>761, the dog will need 762.<n><n>##### 2. If the dog were hungry, he 863 up.<n><n>##### If the dog 470, he will 471 up.<n><n>###### 865 to make a new list for the rest of the blanks.<n>866 then, write how many of the words you chose a separate piece of paper.<n>867 your work to the teacher at the end.<n>

Choices:  A: burned B: polished C: carved D: composted E: nailed<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Explanation:<n>When wooden material burns, the heat burns the molecules apart, causing it to lose its shape.  In its new shape, the molecular makeup resembles the refractive properties of glass in the way light is reflected.<n><n>### Input : How much water can the average human consume during the course of a year? Choices: A: 35 gallons B: 356 gallons C: 3,560 gallons D: 35,600 gallons E: 35,000,000 gallons<n><n>### Response :  Answer: A<n><n>### Explination:<n>An average person is estimated to consume roughly 30 liters of water every day, which comes out to 35 gallons per year.<n><n>###Input: Every time Sally and Henry meet for dinner, the restaurant charges $20 per person as a service fee. Answer: E<n>###Response:<n>12 * 12 * 20 * 30 * 12 = 41,040 * 365 = 14,970,400<n><n>###Explanation:<n>The fee of $14,971,040 per year makes perfect sense.<n>
