On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Eating breakfast in bed can make you feel what, assuming that you don't spill anything? Choices:  A: vomiting B: pleasure C: happiness D: contentment E: mess<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n><n>| Option | Response |<n>| ----- | ------ |<n>| A | B<n>| B | A<n>| C | A<n>| D | E<n>| E | D<n>| F | B<n><n><n><n>### Input;What does one call someone who has been deceived? Choices: A: a sucker B: a conman C: a chump D: a mug E: a fool<n><n>### Response<n><n>| Option | Option | Response |<n><n><n>| A | B | 1 |<n><n>| B | A | 2 |<n><n>| * C * | D | None<n><n>| D | E | 3<n><n>| * E * | * D * | 4<n><n>| F | C | 5<n><n>### Input :<n>Lisa eats 0.5lb of cheese and 0.5lb pepperoni for dinner every day. How long does her cheese last?<n><n>### Response :<n><n><n>| Option  | Option A | Option B | Option C | Option D | Option E  | Option F |<n> <n>| * A * | * B * | * C * | * D *  | * E * | * F * | 1 |<n> <n>| 1 | 0.5lb | 17.7 days | 18.6 days | 18 days | 0.612 lb | 2 |<n> <n>| | | | | | | 0.64 lb of pepperoni<n><n>### Input<n>:How long has John worked at this shop? Choices: A- 4 years B- 5 years C- 6 years D- 7 years<n><n>### Response 3:<n><n>| Option | Options | Response Option |<n>| -----  |---- | ----- |<n>| _A_ | _B_ | 4 years |<n>| _B_ | _A_ | 6 years |<n>| _C_ | _A_<n><n>| | | |<n>| | | 5 years |<n>| | | | <n>| | _A_ | |<n>| | 7 years<n><n>| | | 6 years | | _B_ | |<n>| _A _ | _ | _B_ | _C_ | 7 years |<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:The judge did not take this part of the job lightly, the man was guilty but it was his passing sentence that condemned the man to what? Choices:  A: go to jail B: incarceration C: intercourse D: death E: judgement<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input:-140 divided by 5 is what? Choices: A: 2 B: 3 C: 7 D: 12 E: 13

The software should allow the clients to order goods and services through touch screen kiosks and computers.  The software costs $40,000, has a one-time setup cost of $40,0oo, and will be used one year.  In addition to the one-time setup costs, it costs the store yearly $600o to maintain the software.  Assume that the software is utilized three years.  What is the payback period of the software and what was the total payback for the project?<n><n>### Answer:2 years and $14000<n><n>### Explanation:The net present value of this software is $24750.00 which is clearly negative.  This means a $1400.OO payback period or 2 years.<n><n>### In a local gym, there are three people.  One person spends $20,000 on an annual membership and works out 100 hours.  Another person spends $30,000 and works out 2OO hours.  The last person spends $50,000 but works out 3OO hours.  How many hours do all three individuals spend working out annually?<n><n>###Answer: 1500h<n><n>### Explantion:Work out per hour per person: 100/30, 200/30 and 3OO/H.  300=30,001500h.<n><n>### The following are multiple choice questions that can be answered with either yes or no.<n><n>###Choose yes or no to these questions.<n><n>#####A. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:The cabinets were imported from the south. John bought they because he knew that they would look good.  Where might they be installed? Choices:  A: kitchen B: pantry C: containing pots and pans D: in a flight E: mexico<n><n>### Response:		<n>How many inches are there in a foot?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### InlineCode:<n><n>**Example(s)::**<n>|<n>|<n>|<n>### Example<n><n>![](../../images/inlinedoc.svg)<n>```<n><InlineCode>&lt;InlineCode&gt;</InlineCode><n>```<n><n>### Example<n>![](../../images-images/inlinedoc-example-new.png)<n><n>### Example(s):<n>|<n>|<n><n>Input: The average cost of a gallon of milk is $5. Choices:  A: at the zoo B: south carolina C: hen house D: louisiana E: arkansas<n><n>### Response:		 E<n><n>### Explain: Choice 1 and 2 are nonsensical, choice 3 is a landlocked state in the south that is south of many states, choice 4 is a landlocked state east of Texas which is not a southern state, and choice 5 is a state in a non-southern state, which is not south, not at a zoo, and not close to foxes.<n><n>### Input/Output:The city of Davenport is in a landlocked state. If it is not in landlocked Idaho, where is it?<n><n>### Response(input/output): C<n><n>### Explained: The city of Davenport in located in Iowa, and C is correct for this option.<n><n>### Multiple Choices:Another example in which the multiple choice question is wrong is an example that is provided by a classmate. "How many pounds does one need to lose per week to lose weight at a rate of three pounds per month?" There are several answers. I would say that the appropriate answer is D. The classmate says that he feels that the answer is C because the only sensible answer is D. I will provide an image for each answer that is provided to show why they are not correct.<n><n>![](images/multipleC.png)<br><n>"Answer C says 3/4 pound per week, which isn't even enough to lose weight - it's less than 1/4 of a pound!"<br><n>![](images/wrongAnswer.png)<br>"In other words, the answer must be 1, not 3/4!"<br><br><n>![](Images/correctAnswer.png)The weight loss rate of one pound per month is equivalent to loss rate of three pounds. The three pounds can be lost in the period of three months, which is equivalent to a loss of one pound a month. The correct number is three pounds of weight loss.<n> ![](images/correctAnswer1.png)<n>### Input: Which number must be doubled to give the sum shown?<n><n>### Answer: D<n><n>### Response by classmate: This question is asked in a way that I have to consider if the number that is the closest to the sum must be doubled to reach the sum or if the number closest to me must be

She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Sam found a giant hole in the plain.  What might this hole be called? Choices:  A: hill B: gorge C: sandplain D: cliff E: mountain<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input: <n>Sophia wants to buy 60 gallons of paint for her next big construction job. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:A lonely man committed suicide, why would he do that? Choices:  A: suffering B: he was happy C: avoid problems D: unhappy E: end pain<n><n>### Response:		 C, A<n><n>### Input A 1st level of data type 2 nd level of data type 3 3rd level of data type<n>#<n># <n><n>##<n>def solution<n>input = ARGV.first<n>num_choices = ARGV[1]<n>ans_len = ARGV[0]<n>answer = ""<n>if num_choices == -1<n>elsif num_choices >= 0<n>    n = Answer.all.count<n>    next_val = num_choices + 1<n>    last_answer = ""<n>    while num_choices <= n #loop until the next answer<n>        if n == 1<n>            answer << "A"<n>            return answer<n>        elsif n == 2  #if n is 2, we get last_answer and next_answer<n>            answer << "B"<n>            last_answer = "B"<n>            num_choices += 1<n>            continue<n>        elsif n >= 3  #if n is bigger than 2, which is > 1, then we choose next_answer<n>            last_answer == "B" #set a variable for the last number answer, this is B<n>            first = ""<n>            if num_choices >= last_answer #we get first<n>                if (num_choices - next_val) > 0 <n>                    first << num_choices - (next_val - 1)<n>                else<n>                    first << ""<n>            end<n>            last_answer << first<n>            num_choises += 1<n>    end<n>elsif num_to_check == 1<n>        answer = "A"<n>        return answer <n>else<n>  <n>end <n>#input 1 = The input, input 2 = number of questions, input 3 = desired answer<n>end<n>end<n><n>solution.call<n><n>

Calculate the number of goals each player scored.<n><n>## Question:<n># A:<n>## Answer:<n>### First Choice<n>## If two players equal each other, that means there are 150 goals scored by two players<n>## So by total = 150 goals<n>### Second Choice<n>## So by total 150<n>## If they scored the total points are 150<n><n>### Third Choice<n>## If they scored a total of 150 then the other players must also score 60 goals each

The first example was because I expected the prices to be a little higher, the second it was because I wasn't sure what to expect, and the final one was because I didn't expect what happened.<n><n>### Extensions:<n><n>* Use the context and vocabulary from the last few sentences to talk about someone that surprises you about something unexpected.

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:A person takes a seat to watch a movie, where is he? Choices:  A: in cinema B: at the park C: martorell D: jeep E: airplane<n><n>### Response:		<n>Option: C<n>Option D is incorrect: This is incorrect because the only places to watch movies are at the cinema or at a film fest.<n>Option B is incorrect: This is wrong because the martorell is a city, so the answer should be somewhere in a city. For example: Barcelona, or Sevilla.<n><n>Option E is incorrect: This is out of the topic.<n><n>Option A is incorrect: This is also incorrect.<n><n>Option D is correct: This is close to the answer however if a person wants to be in a city they should be in a cinema because of the theatrical feeling.<n><n>Option C is the correct answer: A theater is a public place where movies are shown.<n><n>### Input : 150 = n * (n - 5)<n><n>### Responce : 1125<n><n>### Input and Response<n><n>![](images/1125.jpg)<n><n>### Input  : 121 = n * (n + 9)<n><n>### Response : 144<n><n>### Input<n>![](images/answer2015.png)<n><n>### Instructions<n>Given a number write a program to output the number after you flip it to zero based(0,1,2…).For example if you input 2015, then the output should be 3.

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:A musician is most likely to perform a concerto for clarinet with what type of group? Choices:  A: music store B: orchestra C: jazz band D: rock band E: music studio<n><n>### Response:		B = orchestra<n><n>### Explanation:<n>We have a sentence that starts 'A musician is most...'.  Then we have 5 choices to choose from. The choices are a (music store), b (orchestra), c (jazz band), d (rock band), and e (music studio).  A musician is most likely... b orchestra.  No other choice matches the question statement. Thus we get the answer b.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>A musician is most popular to perform a concer…. 5 choices to choose an answer.  A: music store, B: orchestra, C: jazz band, D: rock band, E: Music studio<n>### Explanations:<n>A. music store is not a correct option for the question it is A musician is most popular...<n>B. orchestra is a correct answer for the question. orchestra is an antonym for a music store.<n>C. jazz band is not correct in a musician is most likely..  this makes the question that a musician is most popular too a music store?<n>D. rock band is an incorrect answer to the question. it is not a correct answer for this question.<n>E. music studio is not a correct answer to the question.<n><n>## Other Problems<n>There are 44 puzzles in the test data. Choices:  A: fall asleep B: relaxation C: deafness D: bored E: calm<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input:"It's time for bed!"- said the mother, as she gently pushed her son back in to his bed."What's time?" protested Thomas.  "You know, it's bedtime!""Bed time is at 7!" Thomas pouted."But I want to play," pouted Thomas. The father joined in. "You've played enough Thomas.""Birds stop playing and go to sleep at 7," the father explained."But birds are not going to college like me tomorrow!" Thomas whined."Tomorrow will come early if you don't go to bed now, " the father said sternly. "Bed Now, we say...""Bed Now, we do not!" Thomas exclaimed and jumped out of bed. He continued, "Bed Now, I don't want to and if I go to sleep at 3:00 AM tomorrow morning, my body probably won't function properly," the father explained."Ok Thomas, you've made your point," the mother agreed."Good night son, we promise to make breakfast for you tomorrow morning," the mother said."Thanks, mom." Thomas hugged his mom and went down to the kitchen where his father was. They hugged and Thomas left in a grumpy mood. What happened when Thomas woke up next morning at 11 AM? Choices: A. Thomas forgot about his math exams. B. Thomas had a headache. C. Thomas had to wake up his parents. D. Thomas went to take a bath. E. Thomas slept until 6 PM."Bed Now, we will do it, I promise," said Thomas. He looked at the alarm clock and noticed that it was 6:15 AM. He got out of bed quickly and made himself breakfast without a second thought."What's for breakfast, Thomas?" asked his mother. "Eggs, bacon, and French toast," Thomas responded, and went out through the back door. "I hope he doesn't come back until 7 AM," the father said. Thomas didn't show up until 7:15 AM. What happened next? Choices: A."Hey, Thomas, where have you been?" the mother asked."We were busy," Thomas mumbled and took a piece of French toast. "What time is it

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:If people are vegetarian, what do they do more of? Choices:  A: believe in god B: sun themselves C: eat hamburgers D: gain wealth E: eat plants<n><n>### Response:		D

After some heated discussion, it is agreed that economics is false.<n><n>### If the statement is False, write False, followed by an explanation for your answer.<n><n>### IF the statement is True, explain why in 3 - 5 sentences.<n><n>### Direction: Answer the following true-false questions.<n><n>### Question: <n><n>True or False? I can only use words that describe the statement correctly.<n><n>Answer:<n><n>True<n><n>### Instution: <n><n>### Question<n><n>True or False: The statement "I don't know how to get around such people" can be false.<n><n>Answer:True<n><n>### Input I: <n><n>##Direction: Answer the following true or false questions.<n><n>##Question : <n><n>True or false: The statement "Today, this will happen" can never be false.<n>Answer: False<n><n>##Question:<n><n>True or false? I can think of only the way to show the question is true.<n><n>Answer: True<n><n>##Question: <n><n>Question: I can give only one reason the statement "You can take any number and multiply it by 2 and the result will always be an even number" is true.<n>   <n>Answer:<n><n>I can only give a reason how the statement true.<n><n><n>##Question:  <n><n>Question: One reason the statement "The number 6 is even" is true is if the number 7 is not even.<n>   <n>Answer.:<n><n>True<n><n><n>### Instucton: <n><n>##Question: Is it true or false that we can only tell whether a color is red without saying that it isn't?<n>Answ:True<n><n>##Question:Is it True or False  that The statement "I can explain why the statement I just said is true" can never be false.”<n>Answ: False<n><n>###Instrucrion: <n><n>##Instrucrion: I can only write "This is true if the word'red'"

Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Where is a monkey likely to be found in the rainforest? Choices:  A: tree tops B: rain forest C: zoological gardens D: great outdoors E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		Answer E<n><n>### Demo:<n>If we wanted to find the monkey in the rainforest (and that's our task), we would need to know that the question is about the rainforest. To find this out, we would read the question, which mentions a monkey. This monkey is the one that the question is concerned with. We also find out more information about the monkey - it's in the rainforest. It's here in the rainforest that we will find it. That is, the monkey is likely to be found 'in the rainforest'. To find out other information about the monkey, we need to read beyond the question, as it has nothing more to say about the monkey.<n><n>### Input 2:There are two shelves in a library: shelf A and shelf B. A total of 400 books are on the shelves of A and B. Choices:  A) shelf A has more books B) shelf B has more books C) shelf A has as many books as shelf B D) shelf B has as many books as any other shelf in a library E) books are always balanced<n><n>### Response 2:<n>Answer:E<n><n>### Demo 2.0:<n>If there were 5 shelves with a total of 50 books, they must add up to 50, or one book for each shelf. If there were 10 shelves with a 100 books, 20 books, or 10 for each shelf, we would get 100 books. Hence books don't need to be distributed exactly equally, they just need to be distributed somewhere close - the answer is E.<n><n>### Note: This challenge is about understanding a question and answering an appropriate question.  You can not just answer any question without understanding what is going on in the question.<n><n>## Resources to Answer:<n>- You do not need math tools in order to solve these types of problems.<n>- You need your reading comprehension to understand the problem, your critical thinking to figure out what the author is thinking, and logical reasoning to put together the solution accordingly.<n><n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:The disease was spreading fast, so what were researchers desperately seeking? Choices:  A: cause spots on leaf B: healthy C: wellness D: ball stopped E: cure<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input :How many people are going to the zoo? Choices:  a: less than half b: 5 c: half d: over half e: 90%<n><n>### Response :half<n><n>### Instructions: The following task asks you to write a program to calculate the average of a list of numbers.<n><n>Write a program called average using the following pseudocode.<n><n>```python<n>Create a list variable nums to store the numbers and a counter, variable i, to store the index <n>of the number.<n>i = 0<n>while i < len(nums):<n><n>    nums[i] = i<n>    i = i + 1<n>    num_average = 0<n>    for j in range(1, len(nums)):<n>         num_average = num_average +nums[i]<n>    print("The average is", num_average/len(nums))<n>```<n>### Output<n>The first 5 test cases should produce the same output value as your program.<n><n>For the first two test cases, nums should have a length of 2.<n>For test case 1 nums should have the values 0 and 20, respectively.<n>For test case nums should have the value 90, respectively.<n><n>For test case 2 nums should have the 2, 3, and 1 test cases.<n>For test case, nums should have the following.<n>```python<n>[40, 40]<n>```<n>For case 3, nums should have 10 values.<n><n>```python <n>[9, 8, 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, 10]<n><n>```<n>For the fourth case nums should have 3 values.<n><n>```<n>[10, 1, 40]    <n> <n>```<n><n>### Solution:<n>```python<n>list = []<n>i = 0 <n>while i < len (list):<n>    list[i] = i <n>    i = i+1<n>num_average = <n><n>j = 1<n>for j in len (list):<n>     num_average = (num_average + list[i]) <n>print

In this question, you will use the following rules:<n><n>- Each integer is summed as follows:<n>- The sum of integers in ranges from 0 to 9 is 50.<n>- The sum of two consecutive integers is always 21<n>- The sum of all even numbers is 102<n>- The sum of three consecutive integers is 63<n><n>For example:<n>- sum of all numbers from 0 to 10 (inclusive) = 55<n>- sum of 0 to 9 + 2 + 4 = 55<n><n>Furthermore, you will need to print out the answer.<n><n>### Questions:<n><n>Input: the sum of all integers from 0 to 5 (inclusive)<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: the result of summing all integers from 0 – 9 inclusive<n>Answer: 55<n><n>Input: the resulting sum of all integers from -3000 to 3000 (both inclusive)<n><n>Answer: 91,043<n><n>Input: the final sum of all consecutive integers from -30,000 to 100,000 (both exclusive)<n><n>Answer: -136,141<n><n>### Question:In the context of the story, what was the name of the cat that caught a mouse?<n><n>### Question:-25 + 25 + 35 + 60 = 125. If his wife withdraws $3500 from the same bank account and the man deposits $2500 into the account, what would the balance be?<n>### Response<n>$6000<n><n>### What would be the value of π if instead of 3.14, it was rounded to only 3.0?<n>### Response: 22/7<n>### What is the approximate percentage of the total population of California of black people?<n>### Response - 6.6%<n>### What is 54% of 42?<n>### Response 22.08<n>### What is ten less than a six digit number containing six zeroes?<n>### Response : 49999<n><n>### What is a sentence with the following word (choose one): 1. fiddlesticks 2. wham b
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:She'd sooner just spray herself with water than the what she didn't like the smell of? Choices:  A: perfume B: air C: fountain D: swamp E: puddle<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Explanation:<n>A is the correct answer because perfume is an odor.  Swamp isn't an odor, puddle is just a small body of water, etc.<n><n>### Input :  He would rather eat a snail than a what the smell of?<n><n>### Response :  D<n><n>### Exaplanation:<n>You can use a trick where you choose something you already know the answer to.  In this case the question asks if he'd ever eat a snail.  So, you can pick a fish.<n><n>Or, you can get a little more creative and ask, what other choices could he pick?<n><n>Here, I chose a bird.<n><n>### The question now is what you think he'd rather do if he hadn't eaten a snail before?<n><n>### He doesn't smell the snail because he will never eat it?<n>Or,<n>The smell of a snail is so bad, there's no way would eat it again, even if it is the only food on the table.<n><n>### There's lots of ways to answer it.<n><n>### Note:<n>A is the only choice that is an odor.<n><n>### All others are not an odor.

If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Where can you get a stray small dog? Choices:  A: living room B: animal shelter C: georgia D: pet shop E: dog show<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demand:The sales manager says that the demand line is horizontal at an output level of 200,000 computers. What does this mean?<n><n>### Response:"It means that, at this level of output, consumers are demanding the same number of computers as the company is supplying."<n><n>### Supply: The supply curve is downward sloping. What does this mean<n><n>### Response"It means that, as the production of computers rises, the cost of production falls. Thus, there is more economic incentive for companies to turn on another production machine. The companies, in other words, can increase the supply of computers more easily as the quantity of computers produced increases."<n><n>### Law/Laws Of Supply/Demand:<n>### Response: "If the demand curve is upward sloping, then this implies a negative relationship between the quantity demanded and the price of goods. In other words, more people will buy more at higher prices, less at lower prices. Demand, in other words, is more sensitive to changes in prices."<n><n>### Shift/Change in Shift:<n>If the demand curve for televisions moves to the left then<n><n>### Response "it means that consumers, when they buy televisions, will pay a lower price but consume a smaller quantity than before.  This could happen because the cost of another product that consumers value more than televisions has fallen, or because the cost of an alternative product that competes with televisions has fallen."<n><n>### Direction Changes:<n>If the supply curve shifts to the left,<n><n>### Response  "the effect on price will depend on how and how much supply responds to the reduced quantity of output. If supply responds more than demand, then quantity demand will be in excess of quantity supplied, driving the price of the good up. If supply responds less than demand, quantity supply will also be too low, driving the price of output down."<n><n>### Elastic/Elasticity:<n>The demand for ice cream cones is described by the equation Qd = 10P – 5; the supply of ice cream cones by the equation Qs = –10P + 10. At a price of $1.80 per ice cream cone, what is the equilibrium output and price?

How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Where would people be looking at some things which can move, but are not moving? Choices:  A: football stadium B: surface of earth C: car show D: opera E: movie<n><n>### Response:		<n>If people were looking at the movement of the Earth, they would say that it was not moving.  Earth is a sphere, with no defined boundaries.  Therefore, one cannot identify where, precisely, it is moving.  If we imagine that people were looking at the surface itself, they could tell that it wasn't moving.  However, they would not realize that the Earth was rotating underneath them, and that this rotation accounts for the motion they see. If people were looking at the planet from outside of the Earth, they could observe the Earth rotating.  It would look as if it were moving without any real movement happening.  In this situation, people are looking at both the movement and non-movement simultaneously.  If people were looking at an eclipse, it would appear as if the moving planet were passing between the observer and the Sun.  Again, no real movement is actually occurring.  If people were watching a football game, they would also notice that the players are moving.  However, the football itself would never move in any of these circumstances.  People would be aware that the football is being tossed and that it is moving, but its motion would never stop, as Earth or the football would never stop rotating.  If someone saw an opera or a movie, they would observe the characters moving; the movements are not real, but are imitations of real movements.  For these reasons, people could not identify what is actually moving or not moving.<n><n>

How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Illegitimate designer handbags will not have a certificate of what? D: muesli<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following problem.<n><n>### Inputs<n><n>| Name   | Price   | Quantity   |<n>| ------- | ------- | --------   |<n>| 1.   | $75    | 40        |<n>| 2.   | $30    | 60        |<n>|   3.   | $45    | 80        |<n>|   A.   | $50    | 100        |<n>| A: B: C:   | $60    | 120        |<n><n>### Outputs:<n><n>| Name   + Price   + Quantity = Total   |<n>| --------- + ---------+ ------------+<n>| A:B:C:D| <n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: <n><n>Output:<n>* A:B:C + $45 (price of each) + 40 (quantity of each) = $1510 (total)<n>* A:B + $22 (price of each)  + 3 (quantity of A) + 16 (quantity of B) = $153 (total)<n><n>Input: <n>* A: B<n>* $50 each (price) + 40 each (quantity) = $2,300 (total)<n><n>In the last problem, the quantity of each item could be given as a float. Do not multiply each item's quantity.<n><n>Input:

How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Where does a marmoset not usually go? Choices:  A: dictionary B: wilderness C: fly D: underground E: colorado<n><n>### Response:		<n>A. Dictionary. C. Underground<n><n>### Explanation:<n>A. The Marmoset is generally not found in the wild.<n><n>B. The marmoset is a rainforest animal.<n>While some live near underground, that's not the only place they would live.<n><n>C. The marmoset would most likely not enjoy being underground, unlike the opossum.<n><n>D. They're too small. A marmoset likely wouldn't want to be in the wilderness on its own.<n><n>E. A Marmoset likes to be around humans, so a cave is probably the last place you would find one.<n><n><n>### Instructions<n>Read a sentence that contains one of these types of mistakes. Choose the part that was omitted by mistake, and complete the statement.<n><n>### Examples<n>The students were having a hard time getting in touch with the professor. The students were having a hard to getting in touch with the with the  professor.<n><n>### Errors<n>The students were having….<n>The students were having ….<n>The students were havin….<n><n>**Correct**<n>It should be "The students were having a problem getting in touch Professor"<n><n>### Submissions<n>When reading aloud, students sometimes speak quickly or skip words. This can make it difficult for teachers to understand what they mean. To help ensure that students’ meanings are understood, teachers should be sure to write carefully and listen for pronounced words that are clear to other people.<n><n>### Test Answer<n>The students were having...<n><n>### Exploration<n>The professor was having an issue of connecting with the students to solve the assignment.<n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Answer: 868<n><n>Input: Stella and Twinkle are filling up a truck with a capacity of 6000 stone blocks at the rate of 250 blocks per hour per person. They work for four hours and are then joined by 6 other people who also work at the same rate. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:When going to sleep what noise does a human make? Choices:  A: loss of consciousness B: relaxation C: snoring D: dreaming E: talking<n><n>### Response:		What noise does a human make when going to sleep? A. A: loss of conscious B: relaxation C.snoring D: dreaming<n>### Instruction to use the correct syntax. On days with late conferences, she takes the last possible train on her normal route and then rushes to the meeting. She walks less than usual because she’s in a rush to be on time. Choices:  A: understand B: were there C: ignorance D: in-between E: ignorant<n><n>### Response:		The correct choice is the one that describes the question correctly.  So it is C<n><n>### Input :Mark didn't like living a choice A: exist B: life D: life C: in-between E ignorant A answer: The only real choice here is if you are an "idiot" or not.<n><n>### Input Mark had a choice from A: life B: existing C: in between D: ignorance And 2: What did mark 3: choose for the question A: The question C: Life D: what it means to question The correct answer: 1: Existing 2: There're 3: Knowing<n><n>### Input 1: Mark wants to know something about the existence of the world by asking a question in this sentence: "How many things exist in the world?" 2: Mark is trying to answer what is the matter with the world by asking a query in this sentence: "Why does the world exist?" 3: Question Mark is asking the meaning behind the question by asking the question: "How do I ask a question?" 4: Mark's answer is the truth because his question contains all the things in the world.<n><n>### Response What question I ask? (C) The only valid response is if you're an idiot or not. What if I want to know about my own life? <n><n>### Input Why does the world exist? A: The only valid answer is if you're not an idiot. What if I want a meaning B: 7: There are 10: I've been asking myself if there are three numbers 9: The best answer is the question I ask. <n><n>### Response 1: Mark wants the truth. 2: What if I want to answer why does the world exist 3: Mark asked if there were anything interesting in his life 4: Mark didn't want to answer why he was not an idiot A: Mark is correct because he doesn't want to answer.<n><n>### Example:<n>D: the only valid answer is if I'm an idiot. A: the correct answer is if you've been an idiot. B: The only valid choice is if you've already been an idiot. C: The only valid response is when you're not an ass.<n>### Response: The correct choice is the one which

Choices:  A: problems B: crying C: inspiration D: trauma E: nightmares<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### **D**, nightmares.<n><n>### Justification:<n><n>### Remind people of past failure. Not a good idea. Can cause a lot of negative emotions and can be counter-productive, creating more anxiety and possibly cause a person to give up or to not even try in the first place.<n><n>### **C**, inspiration.<n><n>### Reminder what we have achieved in the past helps to keep us moving forward. Can be helpful to keep us moving towards our goal. This can lead us to success.<n><n>### Remembering previous success may provide inspiration to those who fear they will fail but are looking to get better and achieve more in the future. Those who have previously achieved something can be inspired to do so again.<n><n>### ***CORRECT ANSWER***<n><n>### Reminding people what they have already achieved and are not trying to change will make them more likely to continue attempting to follow that goal until they succeed. This will help keep people motivated and on the right track.<n><n>### Answer:<n>

The auntie and daughter's heights are 178 cm and 116 cm respectively. The uncle is 11 cm shorter than auntie and cousin is 34 cm shorter than aunt. What is the uncle's height?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Answer in English<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Answer: 146<n>### Instruction in Chinese<n><n>### 当中有错误时，正确答案始终是错痕正反。<n>### 当错误出现同样的语言时，正确精确度仍然会减少。<n><n>### 误差为0或排位无效<n><n>### 输入1 2 3 4 5 6

How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Why would I want to be exercising? Choices:  A: fatigue B: relaxation C: tiredness D: muscle weakness E: losing weight<n><n>### Response:		 A<n><n>### Demo:<n>```<n>var a = "Why would I want to";<n>var b = "exercising";<n>for (let i = 0; i < a.length; i++) {<n>  if (a[i]!== b[i]) {<n>    return "Does not match";<n>  }<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Demand:<n>I would want to be exercises<n><n>### Inputs:<n>Answer: Fatigue<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The exercise has a question that asks the user to explain "Why would I want be exercises?" and the user provided a sentence that begins with "Why would I want".  The answer of `B` is incorrect because the question does not mention exercising so there is no reason to provide it as the answer.  The other answers are irrelevant for the question, the exercise would not provide them because the answer does not ask for those options.<n><n>### Input<n>Why would I want to go for a bike ride? Choices: A: to improve your fitness B: to exercise yourself C: for some exercise D: to ride a bike E: to be fit<n><n>### Demo<n>```<n>var A = "Why would I";<n>var B = "want to go for a bi";<n>var C = "ride";<n>var D = "the";<n>if (A.startsWith(B) && B.startsWith(C) && C.startsWith(D) && B.length == 18) {<n>  return "to ride a bike"<n>} else {<n>  return "Other: " + B.length<n>}<n>```<n>### Rationale<n>The exercise begins by describing why people go for a bike rides and asks the user to explain the reason.  The user then provided an answer that begins with "Why", with no other option is a good fit for the task.<n><n>### Demo 2<n>```<n>const a = 'Why would I want to';<n>const b = 'go for a bike ride';<n>function areTheyAligned(a, b) {<n>  if (typeof a ==='string' && typeof b ==='string') {<n>    if (a.startsWith(b)) {<n>      return b<n>    }<n>  }<n>  return a <n>}<n>console

The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Where can you buy a binder? If a match did to happen, the draw for the second round will include only the remaining two entries. In the final round, the draw will include all four entries.  Find the number of different outcomes of the final round, if no match is played.<n><n>### Response-If no match is played the four entrants will be divided into two pairs. In the final round there will be two pairs (two entrants each) remaining, and so each entrant will face each entrant of the other pair once, which are two different matches.<n><n>### Input - If a woman and a man face each other in the final round, how many different outcomes are there?<n><n>    If one is out of them and they have played their matches then we have two matches left.<n><n>    Therefore the outcome is 6.<n><n>### Question Input:   The sum of the cube of the first three even natural numbers is 260. If each number in a natural, positive, increasing number is multiplied by 3, and if each product is added to its preceding number, then the sum of the cube roots of the resulting numbers is 36. Find the number n.<n><n>### Sol: First number of the triplets is 2, its cube is 8. Second number is 3, its cube is 27. Third number is 4, its cube is 64. Hence total no. of triplets is 7. Adding the product of second and third number 27 to the first triplet and adding the cube of all of them (2^3 8^3 3^3 64^3) the sum is found to be 395. 395 - 260 = 135. Divid

How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. How many cups of liquid did the two boys drink yesterday?<n>Answer: 36<n><n>Input: Doris works at the Widget Factory in the packing department. She puts 3 widgets in each carton, which are 4 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 5 inches tall. She then packs those cartons into a shipping box before sending it to the loading bay. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. She earns an additional $5 per hour as overtime pay. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week.  On the second week, she walks 2 miles a day, 6 days a week.  On the third week, she walks 3 miles a day, 6 days a week. Finally on the fourth week, she walks 4 miles a day, 6 days a week.  How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:The print was extremely small, as he was reading letter after letter he began to suffer eye what? Choices:  A: strain B: though C: happiness D: realization E: understanding<n><n>### Response:		Answer: A<n>

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. How many hours did filling the truck take?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input: Elijah drank 8.5 pints of coffee yesterday. Emilio drank 9.5 pints of water yesterday. The shipping boxes are 20 inches wide, 20 inches long, and 20 inches high. How many widgets get shipped in each shipping box?<n>Answer: 300<n><n>Input: Queenie earns $150 a day as a part-time clerk. How much will Queenie receive for working 5 days with 4 hours overtime?<n>Answer: 770<n><n>Input: Jodi starts off walking 1 mile a day for 6 days a week. How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:If I have a reception with many people attending, where should I be sure to hold it? Choices:  A: sail boats B: question authority C: high fives D: share things E: learn from each other<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Write a program to play with this data set.<n><n>### Input:[3, 2, 1, 3]<n><n>\```python<n>input = (12, 8, 3, 20)<n>input_length = len(input)<n>for i in range(0,input_length):<n>    print(i + 1, input[i], end = " ")<n>```<n><n>### Output: 1 2 3 4 12 8 3 20<n><n>### Instractions:Define a variable, which contains the number of rows in the matrix and print this number.<n><n>\```python    <n>row_count = len(array)<n>print(row_count)<n>```

How many miles has she walked in 4 weeks?<n>Answer: 60<n><n>### Input:Bill was awaking, what was happening to him physiologically? Choices:  A: tiredness B: grogginess C: discomfort D: getting out of bed E: eyes opening<n><n>### Response:		<n>**2.B:** Bill was grogginess because of being awake and still being fatigued.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>During this time we have  a disruption of sleeping cycle at the same time the waking time is still within the same time the person is still fatigued of the day before which cause us to be groggy.<n><n>### Input A:Johns went to the gym 2 times a week.  One hour was spent on stretching. He only lifts weights another hour. How long does he work out each day?<n><n>### Response A:<n><n>**3C:**<n>Johns went to gym two times a week and when he has two time spend 50 minute for stretching and 50 minute lifting with the total of his time to workout in 100 minute.<n><n>### B:One kilogram of nuts that cost $12 and one pound of dried fruit that costs 8. How much did the purchases cost?<n><n>### B Response:<n><n>**2D:**<n>This question can be easily solve by adding two numbers together.<n><n>### C:Adam bought 3 Kilograms of nuts. 2.5kg of dried fruits  How much did he costs?<n><n>### C response:<n><n>**2A:**<n>we have a quantity of the item and we need to calculate what is the total amount of the cost.<n><n>### D:John was 3 times a week gym.  He spent 1 hour on weight lifting. He also spent a third of his weight time lifting and a warmup as well as spending 1 hour. How many hours does he spent a week in gym?<n><n>### D response:<n><n>**4A:**<n>In this question have two number one is how much number is spent by time lift and two is the time spent in gym per week.  I found the answer by adding them up.<n><n>### E Johnny eat 512-oz can of pops plus 64-oz water a day. How many oz of fluid does she drinks a week?<n><n>### E response<n><n>**2B:**<n>we have the two numbers and in order to get the answer is not
